marketing_content.original_text: Gambia Holidays Why book Gambia holidays Best places to stay in Gambia Most popular Gambia hotel deals Your guide to Gambia holidays Your Gambia questions answered Gambia weather Top Gambia holiday destinations Beautiful beaches Great national parks

website_content.original_text: Manage My BookingFAQFlights + HotelHotelsDeparture airportAny airportWhenAny dateHow long7 nightsRoom(s)1 Room / 2 AdultsSearchAny airport / 7 nights / 1 Room / 2 Adultsexpand search formSearchCheck-in - Check-outAny dateRoom(s)1 Room, 2 Adults SearchGambia HolidaysUTC+00:00GMD: Gambian dalasiEnglishDiscover the hidden gem of West Africa with a holiday to The Gambia. This small but mighty country packs a punch when it comes to unique experiences and breathtaking landscapes. With its stunning sandy beaches, lush tropical forests and vibrant culture, The Gambia is a haven for intrepid holidaymakers.Nature lovers will be in their element exploring the diverse wildlife of Kiang West National Park or cruising down the majestic River Gambia. For a taste of local life, head to the bustling markets of the capital Banjul where you can haggle for kaleidoscopic textiles and handcrafted souvenirs. Meanwhile, history buffs won't want to miss a visit to Jufureh, the ancestral home of Kunta Kinte, a fictional character from the novel and TV show, Roots.With its warm hospitality, delicious cuisine and laid-back atmosphere, The Gambia is the perfect choice for those seeking a relaxing beach break with a difference. Soak up the sun on the golden sands of Kololi Beach or take a dip in the crystal clear waters of the Atlantic Ocean. And with year-round sunshine and temperatures rarely dipping below 30C, it's also an ideal winter sun destination.Read moreWhy book Gambia holidaysBeautiful beachesUnwind on the golden sands of Kololi Beach and take a dip in the crystal-clear Atlantic waters.Great national parksExplore the diverse wildlife and breathtaking landscapes of Kiang West National Park.Bustling shopping sceneHaggle for colourful fabrics and handmade trinkets at the buzzing markets in the capital Banjul.Top attractionsAlbreda, Juffureh, and Kunta Kinteh Island are collectively designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.Cultural hotspotGo to the Makasutu Cultural Forest for traditional music and dance, canoeing along the river and more.Delicious local foodTantalise your taste buds with delicious Gambian cuisine, from fresh seafood to spicy stews.Best places to stay in GambiaKotuOne of Gambias most popular tourist spots, Kotu holidays provide a wide range of attractions. The natural beauty of the area attracts guests of all ages. The beach area is a fantastic place to relax and soak up the AfricanFrom689ppKololiKololi is on the Atlantic coast on Gambia, surrounded by the beautiful Bijilo Forest Park, which is a fantastic place to appreciate local plants, wildlife, and spot vervet monkeys. The resort has a fantastic ambiance and is the perfect settingFrom729ppBijiloBijilo is a beautiful resort, with unspoilt beaches and no nightclubs to disturb the peace, just a few beach bars that illuminate an otherwise quiet stretch of beach. With only the odd visits from a fruit seller, come to BijiloFrom719ppMost popular Gambia hotel dealsRomantic HotelSenegambia Beach HotelKololi, Gambia1,826 reviews Was 1,738From839ppSave 4%59 pp depositBadala Park HotelKotu, Gambia435 reviews Was 1,411From689ppSave 3%59 pp depositBaobab Holiday ResortBijilo, Gambia110 reviewsFrom719pp59 pp depositSunset BeachKotu, Gambia660 reviews Was 2,106From1,029ppSave 3%African Princess Beach HotelKotu, Gambia313 reviews Was 2,178From1,029ppSave 6%59 pp depositRomantic HotelKairaba HotelKololi, Gambia1,039 reviews Was 1,911From919ppSave 4%59 pp depositBungalow Beach HotelKotu, Gambia1 review Was 1,631From799ppSave 3%59 pp depositView all Gambia hotel dealsYour guide to Gambia holidaysAt a glanceWe loveHoliday typesAt a glanceThings to do in GambiaGambia offers something for everyone, from stunning beaches for sunseekers to lush national parks teeming with wildlife for nature enthusiasts. Water babies can enjoy kayaking while foodies wont want to miss the sights and tastes of Gambian markets.Explore Kunta Kinteh Island: Take a boat trip to this UNESCO World Heritage Site (and ancestral home of the fictional character, Kunta Kinte, from the novel Roots). Learn about the island's dark history as a former slave trading post and see the ruins of the old fort.Discover Bijilo Forest Park: Wander through this lush coastal forest reserve, home to troops of vervet and red colobus monkeys. Keep an eye out for monitor lizards, over 100 bird species and the park's towering silk cotton trees  some over 200 years old!Relax on Sanyang Beach: Escape the crowds at this pristine stretch of golden sand fringed by coconut palms. Take a dip in the warm Atlantic waters, watch the fishermen bring in their catch or simply soak up the laid-back vibes of this unspoiled coastal gem.Visit Wassu Stone Circles: Marvel at these ancient megalithic structures dating back to 500-1000 AD. The purpose of the stone circles remains a mystery, but they offer a fascinating glimpse into Gambia's pre-colonial past. The site also has an informative visitor centre.Experience Serekunda Market: Immerse yourself in the sights, sounds and smells of Gambia's largest market. Haggle for fresh produce, colourful textiles and handcrafted souvenirs or simply soak up the vibrant atmosphere. Be sure to try the delicious street food, from grilled fish to spicy domoda stew.Gambia beachesThe Gambia has an 80km-long coastline, making it perfect for beach holidays. Pack your swimsuit for our top choices:Kololi Beach: Golden sands and crystal-clear waters make Kololi a popular choice. Lined with beach bars, restaurants and hotels, it's a lively spot to soak up the sun, try water sports or enjoy a sundowner. The beach is well-maintained and safe for swimming.Kotu Beach: Just south of Kololi, Kotu offers a more chilled-out vibe. This wide, sandy beach is fringed by palm trees and has fewer crowds. It's a great spot for a quiet stroll or to watch the fishermen bring in their catch.Sanyang Beach: Escape the resorts at this unspoiled stretch of coast. Sanyang feels a world away, with its deserted sands, sleepy village and cool beach bars. It's a popular spot for surfing and fishing, with a relaxed, hippie vibe.Bijilo Beach: Backed by the Bijilo Forest Park, this secluded beach offers golden sands and plenty of shade. It's a quiet alternative to the main resort beaches, popular with locals and visitors looking to kick back. The nearby forest is home to monkeys and birdlife.Brufut Beach: Wide, golden shores stretch for miles at Brufut, one of Gambia's most stunning beaches. It's a great place for a long walk, with a handful of local beach bars to stop at along the way. The sunsets here are particularly spectacular.We loveFood of GambiaGambian cuisine is a delicious fusion of African, Middle Eastern and European influences. From hearty one-pot dishes like benachin and domoda to tangy yassa and nourishing superkanja, the flavours of Gambia are sure tempt any foodie.Benachin: This 1-pot rice dish is a staple in Gambian cuisine. Cooked with fish or meat, vegetables and tomato paste, it's a hearty meal bursting with flavour. Head to the beach bars of Kololi for some of the best benachin around.Domoda: A deliciously rich groundnut stew, domoda is made with beef, chicken or fish simmered in a sauce of peanut butter, tomatoes and spices. Serekunda Market is the place to go for an authentic taste of this national dish.Yassa: Yassa is a tangy chicken or fish dish marinated in lemon juice, onions and mustard. Grilled over an open fire, it's a smoky and zesty taste sensation. Try it at the roadside stalls near Banjul's Albert Market.Afra: These fluffy deep-fried dough balls are a popular breakfast food or snack. Served with a spicy dipping sauce, they're the perfect pick-me-up at any time of day. Grab a bag from the vendors at Bakau Craft Market.Superkanja: This nourishing okra stew is packed with beef, fish and vegetables in a thick, green sauce. It's a comforting and healthy dish that's popular across the country. For a top-notch superkanja, try the local restaurants around Serrekunda.Adventure holidays in The GambiaGambia offers thrilling adventures for adrenaline lovers. Trek through jungles to spot chimpanzees, kayak in serene wetlands, go off-road cycling in national parks, abseil down sea cliffs or try deep-sea fishing for barracuda!Chimpanzee Trekking in River Gambia National Park: Embark on an unforgettable adventure into the heart of the jungle to spot our closest living relatives in their natural habitat. Led by expert guides, youll trek through lush rainforest and observe the playful antics of these fascinating primates up close.Kayaking through the Tanbi Wetlands: Paddle your way through a labyrinth of mangroves, spotting rare birds and wildlife as you go. This tranquil network of creeks and lagoons is a hidden treasure, offering a unique look at Gambias beauty.Off-road Cycling in Niumi National Park: Get off-the-beaten-track on an exhilarating bike ride through rugged terrain. Navigate dirt tracks and forest trails, passing remote villages and sweeping coastal vistas. With plenty of opportunities for animal sightings along the way, it's a thrilling way to explore.Abseiling down Baboon Cliffs: Test your nerve with a heart-pumping abseil down these towering sea cliffs. Under the guidance of experienced instructors, you'll descend 50m to the beach below, enjoying breathtaking views of the Atlantic.Deep Sea Fishing off the coast of Tanji: Set sail on a traditional pirogue for an unforgettable day of fishing on the open ocean. With local fishermen as your guides, you'll have the chance to catch barracuda, grouper and snapper, and maybe even see dolphins and whales from the boat.Holiday typesFamily holidays to The GambiaWith its warm hospitality, delicious cuisine and wealth of child-friendly activities, this small West African nation promises an unforgettable adventure for all ages. Be sure to check out our family-friendly favourites:Tanji Village Museum: Step back in time at this open-air museum showcasing traditional Gambian life. Kids will love exploring the replica compounds, trying their hand at crafts like tie-dyeing and weaving, and learning about local customs from friendly guides.Makasutu Culture Forest: Embark on a pirogue ride through the mangroves of this lush reserve. Spot monkeys, monitor lizards and colourful birds along the way, then visit the cultural centre to see traditional dance performances and wood-carving demonstrations.Tanji Fishing Village: Watch the colourful pirogues bring in their catch and see the women processing the fish at this energetic coastal village. Kids can help carry the baskets of fish and learn about the importance of fishing to the community.Brikama Craft Market: Wander through the stalls of this vibrant market, where artisans create beautiful textiles, wood carvings and pottery. Children can try their hand at batik printing or drumming, and pick up some unique souvenirs to take home.Bakau Botanical Gardens: Let the kids run wild in these tranquil gardens, home to towering silk cotton trees, chattering birds and butterflies. Pack a picnic and enjoy a leisurely lunch on the lawns, or take a guided tour to learn about the flora and fauna.Couples holidays to The GambiaThe Gambia offers a whole new world of romantic escape for couples. From private river cruises to secluded beach picnics, there are plenty of opportunities to spend quality time together in this tropical paradise.Sunset Cruise on the River Gambia: Sip champagne and watch the sun dip below the horizon on a romantic river cruise. Spot birds and wildlife along the banks as you glide past mangroves and fishing villages. The tranquil waters and stunning scenery make for an intimate-feeling experience.Couples Spa Day at Coco Ocean Resort: Unwind with a side-by-side massage, followed by a dip in the infinity pool overlooking the ocean at this luxurious beachfront resort. The serene atmosphere and attentive service will leave you feeling refreshed and reconnected.Private Beach Picnic at Tujering: Escape the crowds with a secluded beach picnic. Your private guide will lead you to a hidden cove where you can swim, sunbathe and enjoy a gourmet lunch. It's the perfect way to spend quality time together in a stunning setting.Sunset Horseback Ride at Fajara: Canter along the beach at sunset on a guided horseback ride. No experience is necessary, and the gentle horses are well-suited for beginners. As the sky turns pink and orange, you'll create magical memories together.Cooking Class at Yabouy Home Cooking: Learn the secrets of Gambian cuisine with a private cooking class for couples. Shop for ingredients at the local market, then prepare authentic dishes like benachin and domoda under the guidance of a skilled chef. Savour your creations together in a candlelit garden setting.Your Gambia questions answeredWhere is The Gambia?Is The Gambia a good holiday destination?When is the best time to visit The Gambia?Where is The Gambia?The Gambia is a small country located in West Africa. Its the smallest country on the African mainland and is surrounded by Senegal on all sides except for a short coastline on the Atlantic Ocean.The Gambia is situated on the banks of the River Gambia, which flows through the centre of the country.Is The Gambia a good holiday destination?Yes, The Gambia is an excellent holiday destination, especially if youre seeking a unique and memorable experience in West Africa.Known for its stunning Atlantic coastline, the nation boasts pristine beaches perfect for sunbathing and water sports. Wildlife enthusiasts will appreciate the diverse birdlife and opportunities for river safaris along the Gambia River, and the warm, welcoming locals and their rich culture add depth to any visit. While luxury resorts are available, budget-friendly options are on the cards too.When is the best time to visit The Gambia?The dry season, which runs from October to June, are the best months to visit The Gambia, as youll experience great temperatures and low levels of humidity.Gambia weatherJan30CAvg. website_content.original_text: Luxotour/Africa/Gambia GambiaOfficially the Islamic Republic of the Gambia, it is a nation in West Africa. It is completely surrounded by Senegal, except at the mouth of the Gambia River into the Atlantic Ocean. Its capital is Banjul, although the largest city in the country is Serekunda. The country is located on the banks of the Gambia River, which gives its name to the country, and which runs through its center and empties into the Atlantic Ocean. The country has an area of 10,500 km and an estimated population of 1.7 million people. The Gambia shares with the rest of the nations of West Africa a past associated with the slave market, which It was the key factor for the location and maintenance of a colony on the Gambia River, first maintained by the Portuguese and later by the British Empire. On February 18, 1965, The Gambia achieved independence from the United Kingdom and since then the country has enjoyed relative political stability, with the exception of a short period of military dictatorship in 1994.It is a country with very fertile lands that have turned agriculture into one of the key elements of its economy, along with fishing and tourism.Programs at GambiaSindola and South GambiaBased on 2 or 3 passengers traveling together.7 nightsWhat to see in Gambia?Makasutu ForestIn the west of the country, there is the Makasutu Cultural Forest, which stands out for its natural variety and the living culture found there.Makasutu Park is a lush green space where you can find various types of nature such as mangroves, a mature and dense tropical forest, typical Guinean forests, savanna and grasslands. The reserve is open to the public for cultural and tourist tours during the day, which has made it one of the greatest local attractions.On a day tour of this park it is possible to enjoy various cultural displays such as traditional dances of the Jola tribe, some singing accompanied by drums and a traditional Gambian meal at the local restaurant. It is also possible to take canoe tours through the mangroves, as well as learn about traditional herbal remedies and even go bird watching on the salt flats along the river.Kiang National ParkKiang West National Park is one of the largest and most important wildlife reserves in The Gambia. It was declared a National Park in 1987 and is managed by the Gambia Department of Parks and Wildlife Management.The park covers an area of 11,526 hectares and is located on the south bank of the Gambia River, in the Lower River division in Kiang West district. The park headquarters is located in Dumbuto Village, an 18-minute drive from Tendaba Village. The Gambia River marks the northern boundary of the park. Three bolons (streams), Jarin, Jali and Nganingkoi, divide the interior of the park into three sections. The park is unpopulated and there are towns located near its boundaries. Most of the park is located on a low-altitude plateau and is mainly Guinea savannah and dry deciduous forests, and also has salt marshes and mangrove streams.Vegetation types in the park include savanna. Guineana and the dry deciduous forest. Tree species in the park include the baobab, red acacia, Pterocarpus erinaceus, Ceiba pentandra, Terminalia macroptera, Prosopis Africana and Ficus species. The park is an important area for Gambian wildlife, as it is home to individuals of most of the remaining mammal species. These mammals include the African clawless otter, antelope, caracal, common duiker, leopard, swamp mongoose, serval, sitatunga, spotted hyena, wild boars and West African manatee. Reptile species in the park include the African python, Bell's hinged turtle, West African crocodile, Nile monitor (Varanus niloticus), viper, royal python and spitting cobra. The park has more than 300 species of birds, more than half of all bird species recorded in The Gambia. Some of the bird species in the park have a very local distribution and are rarely seen elsewhere in The Gambia. There are 21 birds of prey, including species of eagle, falcon, harrier, falcon and vulture. Other bird species in the park include ten species of kingfisher, the ground hornbill and the endangered brown-necked parrot, which breeds in the park's mangroves.SanyangThe tranquil Sanyang Beach, like the coastal area of the Atlantic Ocean that surrounds it, is called by locals simply Sanyang. The stretch of beach is located in the West Coast region in the Kombo South district.WassuWassu is a community in the interior of the Gambia, owner of Janjang-bureh. The Senegambia Megalithic Circles or Senegambia Stone Circles are located in the Central River Division of the Gambia and the Kaolack Region of Senegal. They consist of four large groups of megalithic circles, formed by stone cylinders, which represent an extraordinary concentration of 1000 monuments. The four groups, Sine Ngayne, Wanar, Wassu and Kerbatch all together add up to 93 stone circles. They cover an area of 9.85 hectares and a protected area of 110.05 hectares.Kunkilling Nature ParkKunkilling Forest Park is a forest park in The Gambia. Established on January 1, 1954, it covers 142 hectares. The forest park is located in a village called Kerr Serrekunda on the southern bank of the Gambia River.prevnextUseful information for traveling to GambiaEntry formalitiesNo visa required. Visitors of Spanish nationality only need to have a valid passport with a minimum validity of six months.LanguageEnglish was the official language of The Gambia until 2014, since then the official language has been Arabic. Although several regional languages are also spoken such as Mandika, Wolof, Fula, Serer in addition to Creole Krio. Due to the regional location, there is a good knowledge of French, which is official in much of West and Central Africa, and is widely spoken in countries in the region.CurrencyThe official currency is the dalasi (GMD), which is divided into 100 bututs. You can exchange currency at the airport and at banks and exchange offices in cities. Traveler's checks issued in euros, US dollars or British pounds can be exchanged upon payment of a fee. MasterCard, American Express and Visa credit cards are accepted in most hotels. Bank hours: Monday to Thursday from 8:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m., Fridays from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. Certain banks are open on Saturday mornings.Electricity220V. Plugs are round or square, with three pins. No adapter required.Health preventionsThe yellow fever vaccine is mandatory. Other recommended vaccines: diphtheria, tetanus, poliomyelitis, typhus, hepatitis A and B. It is recommended to follow antimalarial treatment since the country is classified in zone 3. Drink only bottled water. Do not consume raw foods (meat, fish, vegetables, fruits...).ClimateIts climate is tropical, with the months from June to November being the hottest and rainiest and from December to May having cooler and drier weather. Temperatures on the coast are moderate, but they increase inland, becoming very warm in the eastern part of the country.GastronomyTraditional dishes of Gambian cuisine are mostly made from rice (the staple food), with various spicy sauces. However, steamed millet, couscous or cassava are also common.The ingredients that define these dishes are peanut butter (Domoda), okra (okra), palm oil (chew deu terr) or edible leaves such as spinach or cassava leaves. Very popular among poor families is Mbahal, which is rice mixed with grated peanuts and dried fish. Some of the best known typical dishes are Domoda (sauce of peanut butter), supakanja (okra stew), benachin (jolof rice), chere (millet couscous) or chicken yassa (fried chicken in onion).Diferencia horaria con EspaaLa diferencia horaria con Espaa es de -1 hora en invierno y -2 horas en verano.PopulationIt has 1.7 million inhabitants and various ethnic groups such as the Mandingas (41%), the Peuls, the Wolofs, the Soninkes, the Diolas and the Akus. website_content.original_text: ReisezieleAfrikaGambia UrlaubGambia-Urlaub im vielseitigen WestafrikaVom Strand in die Hauptstadt Banjul und in die MangrovenwlderNur HotelFlug und HotelRundreisenReise findenReise findenReise findenGambia im Westen Afrikas ist das kleinste Land des Kontinents und bekannt fr seine reiche Natur. Das Land am gleichnamigen Fluss wird an drei Seiten vom Senegal umschlossen und zieht sich bis zum Atlantik. An der Kste erwarten Sie Sandstrnde, whrend das Landesinnere artenreiche Nationalparks bietet. Auf einer Bootstour knnen Sie Flusspferde und Krokodile beobachten. Kulturell interessant ist die Hauptstadt Banjul mit dem Nationalmuseum und dem Albert Market. Buchen Sie mit MEIERS WELTREISEN Ihren Gambia-Urlaub nach Ihren individuellen Wnschen.Unterwegs im Urlaub: Gambias Weltkulturerbe und LebensgefhlGambia steht nicht nur fr Strand- und Badeurlaub, sondern hat auch kulturell viel zu bieten. Die kleine Insel Kunta Kinteh im Gambia-Fluss gehrt zum UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe. Einblicke in das afrikanische Lebensgefhl bieten der Serrekunda Market oder der Albert Market im Zentrum Banjuls.Westafrikanische Kultur im Urlaub in GambiaDa Gambia im Vergleich zu anderen afrikanischen Lndern recht klein ist, knnen Sie die verschiedenen Facetten des Landes in kurzer Zeit erkunden. Der Gambia-Fluss bietet dafr beste Voraussetzungen: Er durchzieht das Land und beheimatet vielfltige Tier- und Vogelarten. Bootsfahrten auf dem Fluss sind eine gute Gelegenheit, die Tierwelt zu beobachten. Die Mischung aus Strnden entlang der Atlantikkste, historischen Sttten wie James Island und kulturellen Festivals ist eine gute Voraussetzung fr einen vielseitigen und authentischen Gambia-Urlaub. Das Land in Westafrika ist auch fr seine Gastfreundschaft und freundlichen Einheimischen bekannt.Die Kultur Westafrikas knnen Sie whrend Ihrer Gambia-Reise in der Hauptstadt Banjul hautnah erleben. Hier wird auf ffentlichen Pltzen getrommelt und gespielt, Straenmrkte wie der Serrekunda Market laden zum Flanieren und Entdecken ein. An allen Ecken duftet es nach Gewrzen und Gerichten wie Maafe, einem Eintopf mit Erdnusssoe. Sehenswrdigkeiten wie der Triumphbogen Arch 22 und das Nationalmuseum spiegeln die Geschichte des Staates wider. Sehenswert ist auch der einstige Trinkbrunnen King George Memorial Fountain am Versammlungs- und Sportplatz July 22nd Square.Naturschutzgebiete, Mangroven und Steinkreise: Ausflugsziele fr den Urlaub in GambiaIm Gambia-Urlaub gibt es eine ganze Reihe lohnender Ausflugsziele. Eines davon ist der Nationalpark Tanbi Wetland Complex an der Mndung des Flusses Gambia, der mit Mangrovenwldern und Gezeitenlagunen fasziniert. Affen, Sumpfmangusten und Seekhe sowie Wasser- und Sumpfvgel leben in dem Schutzgebiet. Bei einem Ausflug in das Abuko-Naturschutzgebiet in der Nhe von Kololi am Atlantik knnen Sie Savannen und Galeriewlder bestaunen. Nicht weit entfernt erwartet Sie mit dem Kachikally Crocodile Pool bei Bakau eine weitere Attraktion. Auch die Steinkreise von Wassu strahlen eine mystische Atmosphre aus: Mehr als tausend Monumente gehren zu dem UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe, das teils in Gambia, teils im Senegal liegt.Gambia auf einen BlickGambia ist bekannt fr seine Sandstrnde wie die in Kololi und Bakau, die zum Entspannen und Wassersport einladen.Bei einer Bootsfahrt auf dem Gambia-Fluss knnen Sie verschiedene Vogelarten beobachten und die historische James Island (heute auch Kuntah Kinteh Island genannt) besuchen.In Gambia gilt das Krokodil als Symbol der Fruchtbarkeit, das in Kultsttten wie dem Kachikally Crocodile Pool verehrt wird.Die beste Reisezeit fr Ihren Gambia-UrlaubDie beste Reisezeit fr Urlaub in Gambia fllt auf die Winter- und Frhlingsmonate von November bis Mai. In der Trockenzeit sind die Temperaturen mit knapp ber 30 C angenehm warm und es fllt wenig Regen. Mit 9 Sonnenstunden im Mrz ist Gambia ein gutes Reiseziel, um dem kalten Winter zu entfliehen. Auch wenn Sie auf Ihrer Reise Tiere beobachten mchten, ist die Trockenzeit die erste Wahl: Dann versammeln sich die Tiere an den Wasserstellen. Whrend der Regenzeit kann es zu starkem Niederschlag kommen, insbesondere im August. Sie ist eine gute Zeit fr all jene, die die Landschaft der Nationalparks in ppigem Grn erleben mchten.Das Klima fr Ihre Gambia-Reise auf einen BlickIn Gambia dauert die Regenzeit von Juni bis Oktober, wobei es vor allem von Juli bis September ausgiebig regnet.Die Trockenzeit dauert von November bis Mai. Die Temperaturen liegen dann bei 31 bis 34 C.Mit 9 Stunden Sonne am Tag und 34 C ist der Mrz der wrmste Monat des Jahres in Gambia und ein guter Zeitpunkt fr eine Auszeit vom deutschen Winter.Klimatabelle von GambiaMax. Er ist ein heiliger Ort, an dem Besucher die Mglichkeit haben, die Tiere hautnah zu erleben und in die Kultur und Spiritualitt Gambias einzutauchen.Gambias mystische Welt: der Kachikally Crocodile Pool bei BakauDer Kachikally Crocodile Pool in der Nhe von Bakau ist eine der Top-Attraktionen in Gambia. website_content.translated_text: DestinationsAfricaGambia HolidaysGambia Holidays in Diverse West AfricaFrom the Beach to the Capital Banjul and the Mangrove ForestsHotel OnlyFlight and HotelRound TripsFind a TripFind a TripFind a TripGambia, located in West Africa, is the smallest country on the continent and known for its rich natural landscape. The country, bordered on the river of the same name, is bordered on three sides by Senegal and stretches to the Atlantic. Sandy beaches await you on the coast, while the interior offers species-rich national parks. On a boat tour, you can observe hippos and crocodiles. The capital, Banjul, is culturally interesting, with its National Museum and the Albert Market. Book your Gambia holiday with MEIERS WELTREISEN according to your individual wishes. On Holiday: Gambia's World Heritage and LifestyleGambia is not only known for beach and bathing holidays, but also has a lot to offer culturally. The small island of Kunta Kinteh in the Gambia River is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Serrekunda Market or the Albert Market in the center of Banjul offer insights into the African way of life. West African culture on vacation in Gambia: Since Gambia is relatively small compared to other African countries, you can explore the country's diverse facets in a short time. The Gambia River offers ideal conditions for this: It runs through the country and is home to a diverse range of animal and bird species. Boat trips on the river are a great opportunity to observe wildlife. The mix of beaches along the Atlantic coast, historical sites like James Island, and cultural festivals are a great basis for a diverse and authentic Gambian vacation. This West African country is also known for its hospitality and friendly locals. You can experience West African culture up close during your trip to Gambia in the capital, Banjul. Drumming and music are played in public squares, and street markets like the Serrekunda Market invite you to stroll and explore. The aroma of spices and dishes like maafe, a stew with peanut sauce, wafts from every corner. Sights such as the Arch 22 triumphal arch and the National Museum reflect the state's history. Also worth seeing is the former King George Memorial Fountain at the July 22nd Square assembly and sports ground. Nature reserves, mangroves, and stone circles: Destinations for a holiday in Gambia. A holiday in Gambia offers a whole host of worthwhile destinations. One of these is the Tanbi Wetland Complex National Park at the mouth of the Gambia River, which fascinates with mangrove forests and tidal lagoons. Monkeys, marsh mongooses, and manatees, as well as water and marsh birds, live in the reserve. On a trip to the Abuko Nature Reserve near Kololi on the Atlantic Ocean, you can marvel at savannahs and gallery forests. Another attraction awaits you not far away: the Kachikally Crocodile Pool near Bakau. The stone circles of Wassu also exude a mystical atmosphere: More than a thousand monuments are part of this UNESCO World Heritage Site, which is located partly in Gambia and partly in Senegal. Gambia at a Glance: Gambia is known for its sandy beaches, such as those in Kololi and Bakau, which invite you to relax and enjoy water sports. On a boat trip on the Gambia River, you can observe various bird species and visit the historic James Island (now also called Kuntah Kinteh Island). In Gambia, the crocodile is considered a symbol of fertility and is worshipped in cult sites such as the Kachikally Crocodile Pool. The best time to travel to Gambia is during the winter and spring months, from November to May. During the dry season, temperatures are pleasantly warm at just over 30C, and there is little rain. With 9 hours of sunshine in March, Gambia is a good destination to escape the cold winter. If you want to observe animals on your trip, the dry season is the best time to go: This is when the animals gather at the watering holes. Heavy rainfall can occur during the rainy season, especially in August. It's a good time for those who want to experience the lush green landscapes of the national parks. The climate for your trip to Gambia at a glance: In Gambia, the rainy season lasts from June to October, with heavy rainfall occurring mainly from July to September. The dry season lasts from November to May. Temperatures then range between 31 and 34C. With 9 hours of sunshine a day and 34C, March is the warmest month of the year in Gambia and a good time for a break from the German winter. Climate table for Gambia: Max. Temperature Min. TemperatureHours of sunshineWater temperatureRainy daysJanuary31 C15 C722 C0February32 C16 C821 C0March34 C17 C921 C0April33 C18 C822 C0May31 C20 C724 C0June31 C23 C726 C5July30 C23 C627 C15August29 C23 C627 C17September31 C23 C627 C15October31 C22 C727 C5November32 C19 C827 C0December31 C16 C724 C0With a package holiday to Gambia, you get flights, hotels, transfers and more from a single source when you book your Gambia holiday with MEIERS WELTREISEN. Gambia is ideal for package holidays, offering a wide range of attractions, from beaches to rich wildlife to cultural experiences. Getting to know the local culture on your Gambia holiday: In Gambia, the coastal region along the Atlantic Ocean is particularly suitable for a successful package holiday. The seaside resort of Kololi is one of the most popular destinations and has a wealth of hotels and resorts, ranging from cozy accommodations to upscale premium hotels. Here, you'll find sandy beaches, water sports, and lively markets that offer a glimpse into the local culture. Nearby towns such as Bakau and Fajara have national parks and nature reserves where you can explore Gambia's diverse wildlife on guided tours. Package holidays in Gambia offer a combination of beach relaxation, cultural experiences, and nature adventures. Kachikally Crocodile Pool: Travel tip for your Gambia holiday: The Kachikally Crocodile Pool near Bakau, Gambia, is more than just a place where crocodiles live. It is a sacred place where visitors have the opportunity to experience the animals up close and immerse themselves in the culture and spirituality of Gambia. Gambia's Mystical World: the Kachikally Crocodile Pool near Bakau. The Kachikally Crocodile Pool near Bakau is one of the top attractions in Gambia. This crocodile pool is of great importance to the local population and is inhabited by crocodiles, which are considered sacred. On a holiday to Gambia, you have the opportunity to observe these impressive animals up close and learn more about their significance in Gambian culture and mythology. The pool is surrounded by a mangrove forest, creating a peaceful and spiritual setting. The Kachikally Crocodile Pool is a place where history, nature, and culture merge. website_content.original_text: Wildlife Holidays in The Gambia Affectionately known as the Smiling Coast of West Africa, the Republic of The Gambia is a tiny country that packs a mighty avian punch, being home to more than 570 species! A kaleidoscope of colour awaits you on arrival, with parrots, turacos, rollers, bush-shrikes, sunbirds and bee-eaters all vying for your attention, and raptors including Black Kite, Palm-nut Vulture and Beaudouins Snake Eagle soaring overhead. Accessed via a direct flight from the UK, and with no time difference, The Gambia is an easily accessible country that offers a combination of superlative bird watching and a warm sunny climate. Speak with our Gambia specialist Barney Jones Operations Manager Email Barney or call 01962 733051 Featured Tours to The Gambia The Gambia in Style An 8-day holiday enjoying the spectacular birdlife and other natural history of ... 8 days | 2,795 The Gambia An 11-day (12-day in 2026) tour to enjoy the superlative, easily accessible bird... 11 days | 3,750 The Gambia in Style - Photography Special A leisurely 8-day, single-centre, photography holiday based at the luxurious and... 8 days | 3,350 View All Tours To The Gambia Our Specialist Recommends "Our Gambia in Style holiday is a relaxing week where we enjoy morning and afternoon excursions on foot and by boat, plus two longer day trips to explore further afield, all from a tranquil and relaxing base. I particularly love Mandinas Floating Lodges, and the chance to watch for Giant Kingfishers from the comfort of your bed!" Operations Manager - Barney Jones Email Barney Naturetrek Tours to The Gambia Between November and April each year we offer monthly departures of our week-long Gambia in Style holiday, based at the Mandina Lodges, set in the peaceful Makasutu Forest and bordering the secluded mangrove-lined tributary of the Gambia River. In addition, each October we offer a 12-day bargain birding holiday which begins and ends on the coast, and in between visits a number of prime birding locations along the Gambia River. What birds might I see? The range of potential species includes huge Goliath Herons, Pink-backed Pelicans & other waterbirds A splendid variety of raptors African Golden Oriole, White-throated and Little Bee-Eaters, Violet Turaco, Yellow-fronted Tinkerbird, Bearded Barbet On our bargain birding tour, the highlight is likely to be the chance to see the handsome Egyptian Plover  Please complete all required fields! website_content.original_text: The Gambia at a glance The Gambia holidays are simply idyllic, imagine a soft golden sandy beach overlooked by palm trees and lapped by the Atlantic Ocean. Just six hours away, you could be enjoying some winter sunshine sooner than you think. Book your Holiday Airports Approx. 6 hour flight time Travel Time 1 hour behind UK time Time Difference Wildlife, national parks and sandy beaches Book Now Holidays to Gambia Description Looking for a holiday destination with a difference? The Gambia holidays could be just what you're looking for. This small West African country, measuring just over 4,000 square miles is wrapped around the River Gambia and offer an idyllic holiday experience with year round sunshine virtually guaranteed. Gambia can be as busy or as relaxed as you desire, the wonderfully golden beaches,like popular Kololi Beach are very welcoming and ready made for sunbathing. If you're in the mood to explore you'll be spoilt for choice with beautiful landscapes, fascinating history and culture. There's plenty to discover. Imagine a 30 mile stretch of superb beaches with soft golden sands, overlooked by palm trees and lapped by the Atlantic Ocean. Book Gambia holidays and you'll experience traditional culture and a landscape that has remained largely unspoilt by tourism. Gambia holidays provide a wonderful opportunity to see some of the wonders Africa has to offer including lush vegetation and exotic wildlife as well as fabulous beaches. The best of all worlds on your African adventure. One of the best things about holidays to The Gambia though, especially if you tend to suffer from jet lag, is you can be by lapping up the gorgeous sunshine in no time at all. Gambia is in the same time zone as the UK and is only a six hour flight, making it even more attractive as a holiday destination. The Gambia is one of the smallest African countries with a rich heritage and is ideal for winter sun holidays. The people of The Gambia possess a genuine willingness to help and Africa's oldest English speaking county offers visitors a truly warm welcome. This friendly country is teeming with vibrant markets and merchants trading against a backdrop of colonial architecture - a throwback to the British occupation in the 18th and 19th centuries. Discover the vibrancy of Bakau, Serrekunda and the capital, Banjul, which is as colourfully African as you might imagine. The beach town of Kololi is one of Gambias most popular places to visit. Spend long days leisurely lolling on the golden sands before exploring the Strip, Kololis main thoroughfare, lined with restaurants, hotels and nightclubs. Brave the bush on a guided safari, chatter with the monkeys of Bijilo Forest Park and bargain for handmade treasures at the Senegambia Craft Market. During the day, fish for Barracuda on the Atlantic Ocean, strike a bargain in one of the many markets and in the evening, sample the wide variety of Gambian and international cuisine. Dine on freshly caught seafood including ladyfish, barracuda, snapper, butterfish, lobster and huge Atlantic prawns. Gambia hotels offer a quality dining experience and most hotels offer some form of evening entertainment, varying from a single kora player to a lively stage show or an African dance troupe. Las Vegas it isn't, but there is a casino and there are a number of bars and clubs that stay open until the early hours - these are located mainly in Kololi. In the evenings, you will have the choice of staying within your hotel or enjoying dinner and drinks in the wide range of restaurants and bars either nearby or a short taxi ride away. Gambia is fast gaining an international reputation with a wide choice of restaurants from casual beach bars to formal gourmet dining, serving a range of cuisine from Italian to Lebanese. During your holiday, souvenirs can be bought in Banjul at the craft market across from MacCarthy Square and at Bengdulalu. One of the most popular purchases is the Gambishirt, made of printed and embroidered cotton cloth, mostly in bright colours. Popular items purchased by those taking holidays in Gambia include wood carvings, beaded belts, silver and gold jewellery and ladies handbags are also popular items. The Gambia holidays are a journey into a tropical oasis with a wide range of activities to keep you occupied and to suit even the most discerning traveller. If you're in search of an all inclusive holiday, a family holiday or in need of some winter sunshine, then a holiday to Gambia could be the perfect choice. Things To Do The Gambia Holidays - Excursions Make your Gambia holidays extra special and book one of our wonderful excursions. Carefully selected to cater for everyone's interests, here's just a few of our most popular excursions to tempt you. Your holiday can be a memorable one from river cruising, fishing, village tours, to African wrestling, bird watching, trekking, horse and camel riding, and adventure trips. Musical events, evening entertainment, cultural orientation, and sporting events. Jeep Safari: Not like any other jeep safari you might have been on. When all the pick-ups are done we depart for Sukuta (which means "new settlement" in Madinka) to see the local market and mosque. Your drive then takes you through farming areas and forest parks and a stop is made to walk through the forest, where monkeys maybe seen. We then proceed to the beach for lunch where you can relax, soak up some of the sun and have a swim for a couple of hours. Driving back along the coast is a beautiful site and you pass by many fishing villages, one being Tanje one of the busiest in the area. Here you see the men taking in their daily catch and the women gathering and cleaning the fish. 3-Day Mini Safari: An early start begins with a drive to Makasutu Cultural forest. On this trip water birds, mud skippers, fiddler crabs, green velvet monkeys and women collecting oysters by the shore can all be seen while taking in the great views this part of Gambia has to offer. During your trip to Makasutu you have the option to visit the craft market, where carvings, sculptures, textiles and other African artifacts can be seen and purchased. The following day we proceed to Tendaba camp. On arrival a boat trip is organised on the "bolongs" which are the tributaries of the River Gambia. You then head back to Sindola Camp for relaxation and a chance to freshen up by the pool, and dinner is followed by a magnificent traditional Jola dance that will be one of the highlights of your trip. Nature Explorer: Gambia is considered to be a paradise for birdwatchers. This is a trip which starts in the early hours of the morning and first takes us to Lamin Lodge, which is located on the famous Lamin Creek. After drinks we get into dug out canoes and silently paddle through the creeks, trying not to disturb the birds and surrounding nature. This is truly a relaxing and enjoyable trip as the water and creeks are so calm and peaceful at this time of the day. The trip on the creeks lasts about 1 hour 30 minutes, after which we head back to Lamin Lodge. Following breakfast we rejoin the coach and head to Abuko Nature Reserve. At the Nature Reserve you go on a forest walk and observation. You also visit a traditional educational centre, while passing an abidance of wildlife and plants. These are just a few of the exciting days and nights out available from your representative in resort. We strongly advise you to confirm your place at the Welcome Get Together as places are limited and we don't want you to miss out. Things To See City Sights: A visit to the capital city, Banjul, to experience the hustle and bustle of the main market and learn about the local batik art and tie-dye crafts. Southern Gambia: This is a great way to experience the real Gambia taking a trip aboard Swiss army trucks, heading south towards the border with Senegal. A real forage through the bush, passing local villages where children will welcome you with songs from the past. After lunch there is chance to swim from a deserted beach before visiting the largest fishing project in the area. Cape Point: A small resort on the West coast, Cape Point's key attraction is a long golden beach. Visit the local market and pick up a bargain or two and if you travel a little further then you will com to the Botanical Gardens - created in colonial times and ideal for wildlife spotting. Kotu: This tranquil resort boasts a lovely sandy beach with relaxing bars to while away the day. Kololi is just a short taxi ride away if you want more choice of bars and restaurants. Top hotels in The Gambia Ocean Bay Hotel and Resort The Gambia Cape Point Senegambia Beach Hotel Plus The Gambia Kololi Sunset Beach Hotel The Gambia Kotu Transport Taxis: Local taxis are widely available, with fares depending on the distance and duration of the trip. 'Town taxis' are painted yellow and are used mostly for local trips around Banjul and the Atlantic coast resorts. 'Tourist taxis' are painted green and can go anywhere in the country. Most hotels have Taxi ranks outside. Climate Best time to go to The Gambia Located midway between the Tropic of Cancer and the Equator, The Gambia enjoys virtually uninterrupted sunshine and high daytime temperatures with almost no rainfall from the month of November and all the way to June. On the coast, The Gambia experiences only mild fluctuations in temperature from winter to summer. Date last updated: 09 May 2025

With non-stop warm weather and fantastic hospitality, you can relax here all year round.Get ready to experience a treasure trove of alluring beaches, vibrant markets, and lively festivals - we're talking about The Gambia! Tucked inside Senegal, this cheeky little West African gem has an infectious energy that will sweep you off your feet. If youre hunting for your next exotic holiday destination, you've come to the right place.Ding, ding, ding! Here are some absolute corkers, the best of Gambia's highlights:Smashing sunsets over the River GambiaHaggling for treats at the bustling Albert MarketSpotting colourful birds at Abuko Nature ReserveExploring the rustic charm of the Makasutu Cultural ForestMarvelling at the haunting Kunta Kinteh IslandWhat are the best beaches in The Gambia?Fancy yourself a bit of a beach bum, do ya? Perfect, because Gambia has sandy stretches that will make your heart skip a beat! Kololi Beach: It's the heart of the sun-kissed strip, buzzing with beach bars and water sports.Kotu Beach: The perfect chill-out spot, famous for its sunset views and beachside eateries.Cape Point Beach: Tranquil and pristine, great for long beach walks and birdwatching.Bijilo Beach: Nestled near the Bijilo Forest Park, it's a great place for wildlife spotting.Bakau: Colourful boats and a buzzing fish market make this beach.Batokunku: The undisturbed flat sands of this peaceful beach line up with the horizon to create the perfect sunset scene.Read MoreWeather in The GambiaJAN24CFEB26CMAR26CAPR27CMAY27CJUN28CJUL28CAUG27CSEP27COCT27CNOV26CDEC25CThe Gambia enjoys virtually uninterrupted sunshine and high temperatures all year round. There are 2 distinct seasons, wet and dry.From July to October the temperatures rise combined with sharp showers, but these occur mainly at night.The best time to visit is between November and March when it's dry and warm.View destination on a mapFAQsHow long does it take to fly to The Gambia?It takes about six and a half hours to fly to The Gambia from the UK. Whats the time difference between the UK and The Gambia?The Gambia is one hour behind the time in the UK. What currency do they use in The Gambia?The official currency of The Gambia is the Gambian Dalasi.What language do they speak in The Gambia?The official language of The Gambia is English. Get those comfy shoes on, because weve got a list that's brimming with adventures! The capital city, Banjul, is home to the famed Arch 22 and the African Heritage Museum  a day here and youll be buzzing with excitement. For a bit of local life, head to Serrekunda, Gambia's largest town, where colourful markets and busy streets promise an experience like no other. And don't forget to take a leisurely boat ride down the River Gambia, where you can spot monkeys, hippos, and if you're really lucky, even dolphins! And thats not in why not try one of theseTake a river cruise along the Gambia River for splendid views.Birdwatchers, head to Tanji Bird Reserve.Dare to wrestle? Visit a local village and learn traditional Gambian wrestling.Try your hand at fishing in the clear waters of the Atlantic.Visit a local school or join a drumming and dance class for cultural immersion.What events can I go to in The Gambia?If you're one for festivals, Gambia's vibrant events will leave you speechless! The International Roots Festival, a biannual event, celebrates African culture and heritage with music, dance, and art. Or if you fancy a fish fiesta, check out the International Roots Festival (biennial): A week-long celebration of African culture and heritage.Banjul Demba Cultural Festival (December): Features traditional music, dance, and local cuisine.Kanilai International Cultural Festival (June): A vibrant showcase of traditional music, dance, and sporting events.Tanji Village Fish Smokey: Although this happens throughout the year, we thought it deserved a spot here: a look at the traditional method of fish smoking. You'll have a whale of a time!Where's the best nightlife in The Gambia?Fancy a bit of moonlit mischief? Well, Gambia's nightlife has you covered! Think lively beach bars, bustling local dance floors and sultry night markets. Sink your toes in the sand at a beach shack like Poco Loco in Kololi and sway to the beat of African drums while the stars twinkle above. Or, get your dancing shoes on and hit the vibrant clubs in Senegambia strip. We're talking lively beats, infectious laughter and a dance-off or two, Gambia style. Fancy a flutter? Check out the casino in Kololi. And don't forget the lively night markets - they're a hoot! As the sun dips, watch Gambia come alive with energy that's nothing short of contagious.Whats the food like in The Gambia?If theres one thing Gambians know how to do, it's how to whip up some mouth-watering grub. Dig into a bowl of Domoda, a hearty peanut stew, or sample the national dish, Benachin, a spicy rice and fish combo that will tickle your taste buds. And, if you've got a sweet tooth, you can't miss the Tapalapa bread, a sweet and crusty delight that's perfect for an afternoon snack. Don't forget to wash it down with baobab juice or palm wine!Ready to tuck into some Gambian grub or hit the town? Check out some of our top-spots.Ngala Lodge Restaurant in Bakau: Fine dining with an ocean view.Calypso Beach Bar & Restaurant at Kololi Beach: Chill vibe and local delicacies.Yosh's in Kotu: Vegan-friendly options and live music.Solomons Beach Bar & Restaurant at Cape Point: Great seafood and stunning views.The Green Mamba Garden in Kololi: Pub-style food with a tropical garden backdrop.Key facts about The GambiaFlight time6.5 hrsTime Difference-1 hrCurrencyGambian DalasiLanguageEnglishWill COVID-19 affect my holiday to The Gambia?We are currently closely following the COVID-19 situation and how it affects travel. You can find out the most up to date information about travel to Greece on the FCDO website.Do I need any vaccinations to visit The Gambia?Please check with your healthcare provider for all up to date vaccination advice before booking your holiday.Do I need to pay tourist tax on my holiday to The Gambia?There is currently no tourist tax to pay in The Gambia.Observing RamadanThe Islamic holy month of Ramadan ended on 30/03/2025. The next time Ramadan will occur is between 17/02/2026 and 18/03/2026. During this time, eating, drinking and smoking may be restricted to the hours between sunset and sunrise, and visitors may be expected to observe these practices in public spaces as a sign of respect, meaning some cafs and restaurants will close during the day, restrictions on alcohol sales may be in place, and hotel dining for non-Muslim guests may take place in private rooms. Playing music, dancing, and eating in public areas may also be restricted during this time.HDHi, I'm Holly Day!I can help you plan your trip to The Gambia

website_content.original_text: GambiaTime Difference: EST +5 hours Current Time and Date in The Gambia Currency: Currency Converter  Gambian Dalasi (GMD) Travel Advisory: State Department Report for The Gambia US embassy in The Gambia: banjul.usembassy.gov The Gambia is the smallest country in Africa with an approximate area of 11,000 km2 and is situated around the Gambia River which flows into the Atlantic Ocean. The Gambia is surrounded by Senegal along its entire 740km border. The capital city is Banjul although most of the countrys 1.7 million people leave in Serekendu and Brikama, the two major cities. A former colony of the Portuguese then the British. The Gambia was the first trade site for the Europeans due to its ideal location on the Gambia River. Permanent Mission of the Gambia to the United Nations Official website of the Permanent Mission of the Gambia to the United Nations in New York City List of all embassies, high commissions, and consulates of The Gambia Addresses and contact information of all diplomatic missions of The Gambia Climate Wet Season: June to October; Average high temperature of 86F and low of 73F Dry Season: November-May; Average high temperature of 75F and low of 60F Communications: Dial 011 followed by country code 220 Language: English is the official language. African languages widely spoken are Wolof and Mandeka UNESCO World Heritage Sites Kunta Kinteh Island and Related Sites This site showcases the different phases and facets African-European relations from the 15th-18th centuries and an important tangible reminder of the slave trade era. Kunta Kinteh Island is in the Gambia River which was the first trade route to inland Africa. The site also contains remains of European Settlements including forts and batteries and well as historical villages. Stone circles of Senegambia This site contains four large groups of stone circles that include 1000 monuments which are stretched along the River Gambia. The remains suggest a sacred landscape which was created over more than 1500 years between 3rd Century BC and 16th Century AD and signal the existence of a highly organized and prosperous society.

website_content.original_text: Gambia holidays & tours in 2025 & 2026 | Responsible Travel 2 min summaryBest time to visitRiver cruiseBirdwatching2 min summaryBest time to visitRiver cruiseBirdwatching Gambia holidays Gambia tours & Gambia holidays in 2025 & 2026 Home\Africa\Gambia Gambia OverviewHolidaysTravel Guide Best Time To GoReviews Our Gambia holidays & tours Gambia is one of the smallest countries in Africa, but its narrow borders contain a wealth of natural and cultural splendour. Our Gambia holidays frequently take the form of scenic river cruises, with local crews steering comfortable small ships. During the days you can visit riverside communities that are able to supplement their income from fishing when groups of tourists pass through. Other excursions take in national parks teeming with wildlife, and protected areas where you can spy dozens of colourful bird species. Alternatively, Gambia is often combined with neighbouring Senegal, or enjoyed as part of an adventurous overland expedition taking in multiple countries. We are happy to discuss your holiday and help in any way we can. No bots, queues or awful hold music. 01273 823 700 01273 823 700 Call us until 6pm Calling from outside the UK rosy@responsibletravel.com Gambia Map & Highlights The smallest country in mainland Africa, Gambia sits on the West African coast and is bordered by Senegal on all sides. Its a narrow strip of mainly low plateau, which decreases in height as it gets closer to the Atlantic coast. While Gambia may be small, its landscape is rich and varied, ranging from the 80km sweep of golden beaches and mangrove swamps along the coast, to the thick forests and savannah of the interior. All this is bisected by the wildlife rich River Gambia, which slices through the country from the east to the ocean at the capital, Banjul. Other than a few main highways, roads outside urban centres tend to be poor and can be impassable in the rainy season. Organised tours keep things simple as youll be driven by an experienced guide in a private vehicle and visit communities without disrupting local life. Give us a call to help with your itinerary 1. Abuko Nature Reserve2. Banjul3. Bao Bolong Wetland Reserve4. Kiang West National Park5. Tanji Bird Reserve6. Wassu Stone Circles Abuko Nature Reserve 1. Abuko Nature Reserve Popular with day trippers from Banjul, Abuko Nature Reserve is incredibly diverse given its petite 2 sq km size. Its home to thousands of plant species, and around 270 species of bird make their home in the verdant forest canopy. Theres a healthy group of mammals here too, including red colobus monkeys, bushbucks and duikers. Abuko Nature Reserve Banjul 2. Banjul With an urban population of just over 30,000, low key Banjul is one of Africas least populated capitals. While it doesnt match the dynamism of many other West African cities, this island city is relaxed and friendly, full of dusty streets and crumbling colonial buildings, and home to a fascinating National Museum, a busy harbour and the chaotic Albert Market. Bao Bolong Wetland Reserve 3. Bao Bolong Wetland Reserve Located on the north bank of the Gambia River, across from Kiang West National Park, Bao Bolong Wetland Reserves woodland, mangrove forest and salt marsh are justifiably famous for bird watching. One of the best ways to spot some of the reserves 270-plus bird species is via a pirogue cruise through the parks forested creeks and mangroves. Bao Bolong Wetland Reserve Kiang West National Park 4. Kiang West National Park Kiang West is the largest national park in Gambia. Spread across 115 sq km of woodland and savannah on the southern banks of the Gambia River, its home to over 300 species of bird, including raptors, vultures and harrier eagles. Other wildlife common in the area includes West African manatees, otters, sitatungas and roan antelopes; and if youre very lucky you may even spot a hyena or a leopard. Tanji Bird Reserve 5. Tanji Bird Reserve The Tanji Bird Reserve is a narrow strip of dunes, lagoons and woodland, squeezed between the ocean and the main coastal road. Despite its small size around 300 species of birds have been recorded here, including several raptors. Its also home to Bijol Island, a protected breeding ground for Caspian terns. Tanji Bird Reserve Wassu Stone Circles 6. Wassu Stone Circles Set in the dry savannah of central Gambia, the UNESCO World Heritage listed Wassu Stone Circles are thought to be burial sites dating from between 500 and 1000 AD. There are several circles at the site, each made up of 10 to 20 stones measuring between 1m and 2.3m in height and weighing several tonnes. Theres also a small museum here that delves into the stones possible origins. website_content.original_text: Gambia A country which is bursting at the seams with culture, beautiful beaches and unique experiences, The Gambia is a welcoming destination and the perfect place to get a feel for the real Africa. With average temperatures between 29C and 34C, The Gambia is a great choice for holidaymakers throughout the year, although more popular during the winter months. Long stretches of uncrowded coastline, friendly locals and exciting wildlife makes this small country on the west coast of Africa ideal for those looking for a slightly different holiday experience. Take me to The Gambia Experience website. Culture and people Known as the smiling coast, its the friendly locals that certainly keep this strapline alive. The Gambia is a wonderful place for holidaymakers to experience traditional Gambian culture, in the form of tasty food, African drumming and dancing, plus the vibrant and bustling local markets. Beaches With long stretches of golden coastline which are generally uncrowded even at peak times, you wont struggle for space to settle down and enjoy the African sunshine. Coconut palms on many of the beaches offer welcome shade, and the occasional fruit lady will come to offer some tasty fresh fruit, should you wish to purchase any. Experiences With a fantastic array of wildlife to discover, along with tours of local schools and villages, you dont have to travel far to get a real feel for local life and the natural beauty of The Gambia. River cruises and 4x4 tours are some great ways to get out and about and see the animals and colourful birds, and trips to local schools are particularly rewarding as the children love visitors. Something a number of holiday-makers like to do is to take along some pencils to give to the teacher for the class.  Visit The Gambia Experience website

website_content.original_text: RejsemlAfrikaGambia Vis billederVis billeder(41) Rejser til GambiaDin rejse til Gambia bliver en spndende blanding af naturoplevelser, folkeliv, lokal kogekunst og masser af sol.Gambia er et lille land med mange oplevelser og kilometerlange strande ud til Atlanterhavet. Tag for eksempel med p en sejltur langs Gambiafloden, oplev atmosfren og det myldrende folkeliv p markederne i Banjul eller nyd de varme solstrler - ret rundt. Du kan ogs bestille en rundrejse i Gambia og Senegal, der byder p masser af natur, kultur og spndende oplevelser.Hoteller p strandenNr du rejser med Spies til Gambia, har du en hel del at vlge imellem. Cape Point-omrdet er velegnet til dig, der nsker at bo enkelt. Her er du ogs tt p flere lokale markeder, hvor du kan gre fund blandt kunsthndvrk, frugt og tekstiler i batik. Vil du have mere fred og ro, foreslr vi, at du vlger et hotel i Kotu- eller Bijiloomrdet. For dig, der foretrkker at bo i begivenhedernes centrum, er Kololi og Senegambia de bedste bud. Lige uden for hotellerne, som f.eks. ved Senegambia Beach, er der et godt udvalg af restauranter, barer og forlystelsesliv. Uanset hvad du vlger, kan du altid finde et hotel til en god pris ved stranden, s du ikke har langt til et dyp i de salte blger.Afslapning i GambiaEfter en lang dag p stranden er det sknt at sl sig ned ved hotellet og slappe af med en drink fr middagen. P denne tid af dagen, lige fr den fantastiske solnedgang, samles turister og lokale p stranden for at spille fodbold og beachvolley. Nattelivet er stille p de fleste hoteller, men p de strre tilbydes der ofte en form for underholdning. G ikke glip af de populre afrikanske danseforestillinger - en farverig og stemningsfuld oplevelse, prcis ligesom Gambia i al almindelighed.Ls mere om GambiaLs mere om GambiaSpies' gster om Gambia4,4/5Bedmmelse fra Spies gster: 4.4/5Baseret p 90 svarBrnevenligt4,3Strande4,2Restauranter og barer4,2Flere bedmmelserSpies' gster om Gambia4,4/5Bedmmelse fra Spies gster: 4.4/5Baseret p 90 gsters bedmmelse.Strande4,2Restauranter og barer4,2Natteliv3,6Aktiviteter og oplevelser3,9Shopping3,6Brnevenligt4,3Find dit hotelTips og nyttig infoHoteller p strandenPrisvenlige hotellerSolsikkertBehageligt klimaKilometerlange sandstrandeLokale restauranter Find din rejse til Gambia StrandStrandene er flere kilometer lange og 20 til 50 meter brede, alt afhngigt af hj- og lavvande. Strandene har fint sand og er ikke specielt lavvandede. P Atlanterhavssiden kan blgerne vre store, og understrmme kan forekomme. Hvis du vil besge en anden strand end den nrmest hotellet, er det nemmest at tage en taxi eller jeep. De fleste hoteller har private strande, og lige uden for de populre hotelomrder finder du en rkke mere eller mindre folketomme strande, som er adskillige kilometer lange. I modstning til hvad mange tror eller mske tidligere har oplevet, s kan man sagtens vre i fred, nr man gr rundt i omrdet. Solen er meget strk her tt p kvator, s solcreme med hj solfaktor anbefales. Vr opmrksom p understrmme i havet og g aldrig lngere ud, end du kan bunde. Svm aldrig ud mod havet, men altid indad eller langs stranden. Udvalget af vandsportsaktiviteter er meget begrnset. Da Gambia er et muslimsk land, br du vise respekt og ikke bade eller ligge topls p stranden eller p hotellets poolomrde.P sndage og andre helligdage forvandles stranden til et samlingspunkt for lokalbefolkningen, som gerne kommer hertil med picnickurven. Visse aftener kan der vre livlig stemning med musik og dans.SanyangDen mske fineste strand i Gambia. Her kan du nyde en frokost p en af de lokale restauranter, f.eks. Rainbow Bar. Om aftenen samles lokalbefolkningen til grillfester. Sanyang ligger ca. 45 minutters krsel fra turistomrderne. Blger og understrmme forekommer meget sjldent.Cape PointPopulr og velbesgt strand beliggende p nordspidsen af Cape Point, hvor vores tidligere Sunwing l. Der er ingen madservering p stranden, men der er en rkke kiosker p stranden, hvor du kan kbe drikkevarer. Flere af de nrliggende hoteller har egne restauranter. Vr opmrksom p understrmme.Kotu BeachVelbesgt strand neden for hotellerne Bungalow Beach, Kombo Beach og Sunset Beach. Langs med den kilometerlange strand findes en rkke strandbarer, der serverer forfriskninger. Hils gerne p de charmerende frugtdamer, der slger frugtsalat neden for markedet.Palma Rima BeachPopulr strand, specielt i weekenden, hvor mange kommer for at g ture, spille fodbold eller bare slappe af. Festerne sndag aften er ogs velbesgte.PriserLiggestole ved de private hotelstrande er som regel gratis for hotellets egne gster. Hvis du vil tilbringe dagen p stranden ved et andet hotel eller uden for de private hotelstrande, skal du som regel betale et gebyr.Mad, drikke og nattelivMad og drikkeNattelivI Gambia er der mange forskellige slags restauranter, cafer og andre serveringssteder, som er udmrkede, hvis du vil smage landets egen mad. Gambia har to retter, der betegnes som nationalretter: Chicken Yassa, en kyllingeret med strkt krydret sauce (Yassa), og Domoda, som er den mest udbredte ret hos lokalbefolkningen. Den bestr enten af kylling, kd eller fisk og serveres med ris og jordnddesauce. Der bnes hele tiden nye restauranter i Gambia, og udvalget bliver kun strre, s du har aldrig langt til den nste frokost eller forfriskning.VandVand kbes p flaske og br ikke drikkes direkte fra vandhanen.I Gambias turistomrder er der et aktivt natteliv med pubber og restauranter, ofte med levende musik. Mange hoteller har ogs underholdning flere aftener om ugen. I Senegambia-omrdet er der et stort forlystelsesudbud med mange pubber og restauranter samt nogle kasinoer.ShoppingDer er mange ting, som er vrd at kbe med hjem fra Gambia, selvom shoppingudbuddet er meget anderledes end derhjemme. Her finder du f.eks. ldervarer, batikstof og trfigurer. Der er sm markeder nsten overalt, og man kan nsten ikke tage til Gambia uden at besge mindst t af dem. Du kan ofte prutte prisen helt ned til det halve p varer uden prisskilt. Det vigtigste er, at du selv er tilfreds med prisen. Bemrk, at mange butikker og boder mangler skiltning, s de kan vre svre at finde, hvis man ikke ved, hvor de ligger. Dette gr sig isr gldende i omrderne Senegambia, Kotu og Kairaba Avenue i Bakau. Du finder sm minimarkeder med et begrnset varesortiment overalt og lidt strre levnedsmiddelbutikker i Cape Point og Kololi. Bemrk, at importerede varer er mindst lige dyre som i Danmark.Skrddersyet tjHer er mere end 100 sm skrdderier. Stoffet kbes enten direkte hos skrdderen eller i en anden butik, hvorefter stoffet tages med hen til skrdderen. Dette er den billigste mde at gre det p.TrkunstEt stort udvalg af smukke og fascinerende trfigurer slges p de lokale markeder. Det strste trkunstmarked ligger i Brikama, ca. 45 minutters bilkrsel fra turistrejsemlene. Her er udvalget stort, og priserne kan ofte pruttes langt ned. Vr opmrksom p, at du mske kommer til at betale overvgt p din bagage, nr du flyver hjem.Sport og trningI Gambia har du mulighed for at trne og dyrke trning med blandt andet tennis og cykling. Der findes ogs en 18-hullers golfbane i Fajara, hvor du kan spille uden greencard.Aktiviteter og sevrdighederAktiviteterSevrdighederEn god mde at se Gambia p er ved at lade en lokalguide vise dig rundt. Du kan kende de officielle lokalguider p uniformen med mrket 'OTG'. Alle hoteller har lokalguider, som de anbefaler, og er du i tvivl, sprger du bare personalet i receptionen. Vil du besge markedet i Banjul eller Serrekunda p egen hnd, anbefaler vi, at du ledsages af en lokalguide, da de holder alle "selvudnvnte" guider vk. De kan desuden hjlpe dig med at f gode priser p varerne.SelvforklelseI ferien vlger mange at forkle sig selv med luksurise spabehandlinger eller en tur p sknhedssalon - i Gambia er der rige muligheder for begge dele.Abuko naturreservatDette fascinerende naturreservat ligger ca. 45 minutters bilkrsel fra Kotuomrdet. Det tager ca. to timer at komme rundt i parken, hvor du kan se aber, antiloper, krokodiller, hyner og forskellige fuglearter.Brikama kunsthndvrkermarkedDet strste trfigurmarked i Gambia. Her kan du kbe fine souvenirs og gre mange gode fund. Husk at prutte om priserne! Den nemmeste mde at komme til Brikama er med taxi. bent dagligt.Katchically krokodrilleparkKrokodillepoolen med mere end 50 krokodiller. Her kan du hilse p den 30-rige krokodille Charlie og hans venner. De lokale guider i parken kan hjlpe dig med at finde Charlie. Parken er ben dagligt.Ganske vist lokker stranden, men der er ogs andre sevrdigheder i Gambia: kultur, historie, natur og folkeliv.Tanji Village MuseumTanji Village Museum er bygget som en by og er et levende museum, hvor du bl.a. kan se, hvordan det lokale hndarbejde gr til. Samtidig fr du et godt indblik i, hvordan lokalbefolkningen lever i omrdet. Museet ligger i fiskerbyen Tanji, hvortil du kan tage en taxi (ca. 25 minutter). Husk at aftale prisen med chauffren p forhnd.BanjulBanjul ligger p en St. Mary's Island p den sydlige side af Gambiafloden. Her er en stor havn og en befolkning p ca. 45.000 mennesker. Banjul er dog ikke den strste by i Gambia og nok heller ikke den knneste, men den er alligevel et besg vrd for alle, som vil opleve den gambiske kultur. Her er mennesker overalt og en smule kaotisk. P Albert Market, som ligger p Russel Street, kan du kbe alt mellem himmel og jord, isr afrikanske krydderier og madvarer. Lige rundt om hjrnet ligger turistmarkedet med lokalt hndvrk, hvor du kan ve dig i at prutte om prisen!Kunta Kinthe IslandBygget af tyskerne i 1651 og overtaget af briterne i 1661. Kunta Kinthe Island (tidligere Fort James) spillede en stor rolle under slavetiden og fungerede som opsamlingsplads for slaverne. I dag er ens strrelse reduceret helt ned til en syvendedel pga. floden, som langsomt der en op. Kunta Kinthe Island er desuden optaget p UNESCO's Verdensarvsliste.JufferehDet var her, Alex Haley blev inspireret til at skrive bogen "Rdder" om slaven Kunta Kintes skbne. Her kan du ogs besge Gambias eneste slavemuseum.AlbredaAlbredas bermte flagstang er symbolet p frihed til den slave, som klarede sig godt. Denne tidligere slavehandelsstation har interessante sevrdigheder tilbage fra slavehandlens dage.NationalmuseetMuseet ligger midt i Banjul. Her er bde store og sm sevrdigheder med relation til gamle gambiske traditioner og jordbruget fra den britiske kolonisering indtil i dag. Musikafdelingen er ganske imponerende.FaktaVores service p rejsemletSpies har ikke personale i Gambia, men du kan ringe til os dgnet rundt, hvis du har brug for hjlp.Rejser med omtankeSpies vil gerne gre en forskel med hver eneste ferierejse - bde for dem, der rejser med os, og lokalt p vores rejseml. Derfor strber vi hele tiden efter at mindske vores klimaaftryk bde herhjemme, p flyrejsen og p vores hoteller. Ls mere om vores klima- og miljarbejde her. Pas, visum og UMs rejsevejledningFor rejsende med dansk pas skal passet vre gyldigt i seks mneder ud over opholdets varighed. Der krves ikke visum for ophold i indtil 28 dage. Danske provisoriske pas, EU-ndpas og forlngede danske pas anerkendes ved ind- og udrejse. For nrmere information henviser vi til Gambias ambassade i London p telefon +44 (0) 20 3928 9770.Personer med dansk flygtninge- eller fremmedpas skal kontakte den gambiske ambassade for at f oplyst, hvilke regler der glder for deres indrejse.Spies brer ikke ansvar for fejlagtige dokumenter, der kan fre til ngtet indrejse i GambiaUdenrigsministeriets rejsevejledningVi anbefaler, at du henter appen 'Rejseklar' i App Store eller Google Play for at holde dig opdateret om Udenrigsministeriets rejsevejledning for dit rejseml. Du kan ogs lse mere p Udenrigsministeriets side om rejsevejledninger.VaccinationerFor indrejse til Gambia er der krav om vaccination mod gul feber for alle rejsende over 9 mneder, der kommer fra lande med risiko for gul feber-transmission, og for rejsende der har vret i transit (> 12 timer) i en lufthavn i et land med gul feber-transmission. Se hvilke lande det glder her.Ls mere om dette og andre vigtige anbefalede vaccinationer p Rejsevaccination og Danske Lgers Vaccinations Service. Vr opmrksom p, at andre regler kan glde, f.eks. hvis du har pas fra andre lande end Danmark, har mellemlandinger p rejsen eller rejser via andre lande end Danmark.Spies er ikke ansvarlig, hvis du ngtes indrejse til Gambia, hvis vaccinationskrav ikke opfyldes.Love og normerDer findes nationale love, lokale regler og normer p dit rejseml, som kan vre anderledes end dem, vi har i Danmark. Det er dit eget ansvar at finde ud af, hvad der glder i det land, du skal besge. For at undg ubehagelige overraskelser i ferien anbefaler vi dig at lse mere p landets ambassades hjemmeside samt undersge Udenrigsministeriets information om udlandsrejser.Valuta og kreditkortDalasi (GMD). Der findes banker i Kololi/Senegambia, Serrekunda og Banjul. Der findes hveautomater ved en del banker, som accepterer udenlandske kreditkort med et maksimalt hvebelb p 3.000 GMD (ca. 400 DKK) pr. gang. Strre belb kan hves i banken med Visa-kort eller MasterCard. Nogle hoteller har ogs et lille bankkontor ved receptionen. Det er almindeligt, at hveautomaterne er ude af drift eller tomme, og at kortbetaling ikke fungerer. Vi anbefaler derfor, at du medbringer kontanter, helst i DKK, EUR eller USD. Man kan veksle p hoteller og vekselkontorer.TidsforskelDansk -1 time (sommertid -2 timer).El220 V. Adapter er ndvendig p nogle hoteller - kan kbes p rejsemlet (ca. 40 GMD).SprogDer findes otte forskellige folkestammer i Gambia, som alle har hver deres sprog og kultur. Kiertomatkaan voit yhdist mys rantaloman rannikolla. Kiertomatkalla pset kokemaan ikimuistoisia elmyksi, kuten safariseikkailun Fathalan luonnonreservaatissa, Senegalin pkaupungin Dakarin, Goren saaren, joka on tunnettu orjakaupan muistokeskuksena sek vierailemaan paikallisessa koulussa.Lis kohteesta GambiaLis kohteesta GambiaKohteen hotellitKatso kaikki kohteet Matkat  Gambia Tutustu kohteisiimme YleiskatsausKatso kohteemme kartalta.Nyt karttaGambian rannikkoTjreborgin aurinkovarmin lomakohde ei tuota pettymyst. Gambiassa on mys ihania rantoja ja upea luonto.7 hotelliaLue lis SMilloin on paras s Gambiassa?Gambiassa vallitsee trooppinen ilmasto, joka voidaan jakaa kahteen vuodenaikaan - lyhyt sadekausi heinkuusta lokakuulle ja kuivempi ajanjakso joulukuusta huhtikuulle. Rannikolla, Banjulin ympristss, jossa mys Tjreborgin lomakohteet sijaitsevat, pivlmptilat pysyttelevt vuoden ympri 30 asteen tuntumassa. Huippusesongin aikaan, talvella, lmptilat saattavat olla muutaman asteen alhaisempia ja sateita on tuskin odotettavissa. Veden lmptila on tasainen, 21-25 astetta. Sadekausi alkaa hein-elokuussa ja jatkuu yleens lokakuulle asti. Sadekaudellakaan ei toki sada taukoamatta, vaan sadekuurot ovat yleens voimakkaita, mutta melko lyhyit. Sadekuurojen vlill paistaa aurinko ja lmptila on 22-28 astetta. Vuoden viileimmt kuukaudet ovat tammi- ja helmikuu, ja silloin lmptila laskee isin 20 asteen tuntumaan.RokotuksetOn trke, ett sinulla on kaikki suositellut rokotukset  oman turvallisuutesi vuoksi. Maassa esiintyy keltakuumetta. Rokotusta suositellaan. Keltakuumerokotustodistus vaaditaan, jos saavut maahan keltakuumeen esiintymisalueelta tai olet tehnyt vlilaskun maassa, jossa esiintyy keltakuumetta. Mikli teet vlilaskun tai lomailet useissa eri Afrikan maissa, ota selv eri maiden rokotusvaatimuksista.Trooppisessa Afrikassa tarvitaan aina malarian estolkitys. Tehokkaat estolkitysvaihtoehdot ovat meflokiini (LariamR), atovakoni + proguaniili (MalaroneR) tai doksisykliini. Klorokiini (HelioparR) ei ole teholtaan riittv ehkisyyn Afrikassa, joten sit ei tule kytt. Estolkityst varten tarvitaan aina lkrin resepti. Estolkityst on kytettv ohjeiden mukaan mys matkan jlkeen eik lkityst saa keskeytt. Suojautuaksesi hyttysi ja muita hynteisi vastaan, suosittelemme hyttyskarkotetta ja vaaleita, pitkhihaisia ja -lahkeisia vaatteita.Huom! Jos olet lhdss Senegaliin, tarkista, ett sinulla on voimassa oleva keltakuumerokotus. Kansainvlinen keltainen rokotuskortti tulee ottaa mukaan matkalle ja rokotuskortissa tulee olla maininta voimassa olevasta keltakuumerokotuksesta.Ajantasaista tietoa rokotuksista ja rokotussuosituksista saat rokote.fi-sivuilta sek Terveyden ja hyvinvoinnin laitoksen julkaisemasta Matkailijan terveysoppaasta. Huomioithan, ett muita sntj voidaan soveltaa esimerkiksi silloin, jos sinulla on jonkun muun maan kuin Suomen passi, kyseess on vlilaskukohde tai matkustat muiden maiden kuin Suomen kautta.Tjreborg ei ole vastuussa, jos sinulta evtn maahanpsy puuttuvien rokotusten vuoksi.S GambiaSRokotukset
