website_content.original_text: 2025 - THE AFRICAN WEST COAST, 10 days: Senegal & The Gambia | TransAfrica 2025  THE AFRICAN WEST COAST, 10 days: Senegal & The Gambia 2025  THE AFRICAN WEST COAST, 10 days: Senegal & The Gambia Days: 10 Tour Type: Discovery International group Group size: From 2 to 16 participants PRICES per person:- GROUP OF 6 OR MORE GUESTS: 2330 - Group of 4/5 guests: 2660  - Group of 2/3 guests: 2660  (booking 90 or more days prior to departure date) - Group of 2/3 guests: 3810  (booking 89 or more days prior to departure date) - Single room supplement: 340  GUIDE: English, French, Italian speaking Deposit at the booking: 1.156,00 The deposit is intended as 30% of the total. For more information, you can view our information. SENEGAL & GAMBIA Following the uncertain border between land and water we move across an incredible variety of natural environments such desert dunes, savannah, estuaries, forest, mangrove swamps DEPARTURES: 08 November 2025 27 December 2025 PRICE FROM: 2330  You can book online until 30 days before departure. If you wish to book closer to departure date, please contact our sales team on transafrica@transafrica.biz Discount:Send an inquiry Categories: Gambia, Guaranteed Departures, Senegal Special offer Description Itinerary Technical Sheet The quote includes Description SENEGAL & GAMBIA A unique itinerary crossing two countries north to south to experience a continuous change of climatic ecosystems and human environments. NATURE Following the uncertain border between land and water we move across an incredible variety of natural environments such desert dunes, savannah, estuaries, forest, mangrove swamps.Birds will be a constant presence along the whole journey. Djoudj National Sanctuary in Senegal is one of the main migratory bird sanctuaries on earth and Gambia is a well-known birding destination. HISTORY, PREHISTORY & TIMELESS VILLAGES We will discover historical sites as: Dakar, contemporary metropolis, large capital and African intellectual center since the time before the independence. Gore, ancient slave-trade island; Saint Louis, the first colonial capital of French West Africa; We will experience the encounter with timeless people as herders and remote villages. We will discover the largest monoliths site on earth. ART, CULTURE & MUSIC In the northern Savannah we will be invited at the camp of nomadic herders and we will meet the largest religious and peaceful brotherhood that practices an African form of Islam that rejects fundamentalism and violence. In the south, we will be introduced to animistic traditional religions, tribal kings, dancing masks. In the animistic Casamance region we will witness at the celebrations of Diola mask, the incarnation of mythical spirits Masquerade is a unique experience that involves the participation of the entire village in an intense mixt of magic, music, and dances. TRANSPORT We will travel using different means of transport. The variety of cultures and natural environments and routes corresponds to the variety of the most appropriate vehicles: minibus/microbus, 44, local buggy (private use), local taxi called taxi brousse (private use), local cart. DAY 1: Dakar, the capital  SENEGAL Arrival in Dakar and transfer to the hotel. DAY 2: Dakar contemporary metropolis & Gore, from Dakar to Gore (transfers in town and ferry)  SENEGAL Dakar, the large and vibrant African metropolis that was the cultural and intellectual capital of French West Africa. Dakar is located at the end of the Cape Verde peninsula, the western-most point on the African continent and has a population of about 2.4 million people. Nowadays a large and vibrant African metropolis it was the cultural and intellectual capital of the former French West Africa. Being also the capital of Senegal, is currently a window on contemporary art and music and the center of all kinds of creativity. We will visit the Muse des Civilisations Noirs. Opened in December 2018, it is the realization of Lopold Sdar Senghors vision (the first president of independent Senegal, a poet, and Nobel Prize winner). The museum represents the historical and contemporary worldwide cultures, art, and soul of Black people, which he called Negritude. We will also visit the Cathdrale Notre Dame des Victoires. The project to build the Dakar cathedral was initiated in 1910 to pay tribute to African combatants, the Cathedral was finally built in Neo-Sudanese style, a style inspired by the Sahara and Sub-Sahara adobe mosque architecture, and was consecrated on 2 February 1936. Arrival at Dakar port to board a ferry and spend a night in Gore, the island where slaves used to be crammed before being shipped to the Americas. Some restored buildings remain to bear witness of those times. The Portuguese were the first to establish a presence on Gore in 1450, where they built a small stone chapel. After the decline of the slave trade from Senegal in the 1770s and 1780s, the island became an important port for the shipment of peanuts, Arabic gum, ivory, and other products of legitimate trade. Thanks to the nice breeze, and the many restaurants and shops, Gore today has become a pleasant and trendy location. In the late afternoon and evening, when the other tourists are gone, we will experience the real feeling of this special island. DAY 3: Lac Rose and fisherman villages, from Gore to Lac Rose (ferry and drive 100 km driving time 3 hrs.)  SENEGAL Waking up in Gore before the crowd arrives is a pleasure, as strolling in the tiny stone-paved alleys of this historical settlement. Ferry to Dakar and drive to Lac Rose, a shallow saltwater lake surrounded by dunes, also known as Lac Retba. Miles of exciting drive on the beach by 44 (depending on tides) will bring us to discover the largest fisherman village in Senegal. More than 4500 wooden painted pirogues come to the shore with the catch of the day On the beach the fisherman sells to the local market women, after we meet the artisans carving the large pirogues, the painters decorating them with bright colors, and if we are lucky the local saint for final blessing before sailing DAY 4: Saint Louis, from Lac Rose to St. Louis (210 km  driving time 5 hrs.)  SENEGAL Saint Louis, known to locals as Ndar, is a charming ancient town that was a French territory from 1673 until 1895 and the capital of all French West Africa colonies from 1895 until 1902 when the capital was moved to Dakar. From 1920 to 1957, it also served as the capital of the neighboring colony of Mauritania. It has been the former base of the Aeropostale airmail pioneer operation between Europe, Africa, and South America. Saint Exupry, the famous writer, and author of The Little Prince, was one of Aeropostales pilots following this route. Located on two islands between the Senegal River and the ocean at the southern edge of the Sahara, rich in three centuries of history, cultural background, geography, and architecture, Saint-Louis is a bridge between the savanna and the desert, the ocean, the river, and the inland, between tradition and modernity, Islam and Christianity, Europe and Africa. Home to a society with a distinctive lifestyle, Saint-Louis has retained its unique identity. No one comes without falling in love with the city, proudly say its people who consider Saint-Louis as the birthplace of Senegalese Teranga, the Wolof word for hospitability The best way to visit the narrow lanes of Saint Louis is by calash, just as locals do, and walk in the fishermans quarters. Time to stroll in the tiny avenues and enjoy the unique atmosphere of this old town. We will spend the night at the historic hotel of the town  built in 1895 and now fully renovated  it was here that all Aeropostale pilots use to stay. DAY 5: Bird sanctuary & Nomadic tribes, from St. Louis to Ferlo desert (150 km  driving time 4 hrs.)  SENEGAL Early morning departure northwards to discover Djoudj National Bird Sanctuary (Parc National des Oiseaux du Djoudj), a natural oasis formed by hundreds of miles of partially flooded lands that has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This humid paradise between the Sahara and Ferlo desert, is the best habitat and nesting site for over a million migratory and resident birds  lies on the southeastern bank of the Senegal River and offers a range of wetland habitats that are attended by many migrating birds, some getting here after crossing the Sahara. Out of more than 400 species, pelicans and flamingos are the most common, whereas aquatic warblers are a bit less conspicuous  migrating here from Europe, this park is their single most important wintering site yet discovered. Apart from birds, there is also a wide range of wildlife such as warthogs and crocodiles. Motorboat excursion led by a local guide-ornithologist. Depending on the season, considering the time of migrations and level of water, the visit to Djoudj may be replaced by a similar experience in Langue de Barbarie, a thin, sandy peninsula, adjacent to the Atlantic Ocean, located in western Senegal, in the neighborhoods of the city of Saint-Louis. The peninsula separates the ocean from the final section of the Senegal River. The Langue de Barbarie National Park is home to an abundant variety of bird species and three species of turtle, including the critically endangered hawksbill sea turtle. In the afternoon continue to the Ferlo Desert to discover the arid region where nomadic Fulani tribes herd large droves of zebu. The Fulani (also called Peul) are the largest nomadic tribe roaming West African Savannahs, living in a vast area from Senegal to Chad. Their origins are still covered with mystery. They all share a common aristocratic cult for beauty and elegance. In the afternoon a local guide will join us for a visit to the neighboring villages and shelters. When the herds come back, we might even be invited to witness the milking process. DAY 6: Tuba Brotherhood, from Ferlo desert to Kabacoto (240 km  driving time 5 hrs.)- SENEGAL The rarely visited holy town of Tuba (Touba) is the right place to appreciate the hospitality of an African brotherhood. Touba inhabitants follow Muridism and the town itself is a sort of theocratic state within the state, ruled by a Caliph. The founder of Mouridi brotherhood was a Sufi named Amhadou Bmba Mbake. Amhadou Bmba founded Touba in 1887. The holy site remained a tiny, isolated place in the wilderness until his death and burial at the site of the Great Mosque, 40 years later. The Great Mosque was finally completed in 1963 and since its inauguration, the city has grown at a rapid pace: from under 5,000 inhabitants in 1964, the population was officially estimated at 529,000 in 2007 The Mourides have a large social and economic impact in Senegal: thanks to their peaceful (and African) vision of Islam, Muridism, with other brotherhoods following the cult of Marabouts, has become the bastion that protects Senegal from radical Islam. During the Grand Magal, the annual pilgrimage, the town is visited by four million pilgrims. Mourides welcome any interest in their traditions. Yet since Tuba is a sacred town, all visitors should accept traditional rules. Therefore, we must apply a considerate dress code: not smoke, not drink alcohol and not listen to music during the visit. If we follow these rules, we will be welcomed. A Baye Fall, a member of a colorful branch of Muridism, will accompany us during the visit. DAY 7: Stone circles, from Kabacoto to Banjul (240 km  driving time 6 hrs.)  SENEGAL-GAMBIA Early departure, we will leave the main road to discover the unique megalithic site of Sine Ngayene, as part of the Senegambian stone circles, which lie in The Gambia and in central Senegal. According to UNESCO, the Senegambian stone circles are the largest concentration of stone circles seen anywhere in the world. These sites represent an extraordinary concentration of more than 1,100 stone and related tumuli spread over a territory of 100 km wide and 350 km in length, on the north bank of the Gambia River. After The Gambia border formalities, we will drive to the Banjul area. DAY 8: Gambian birds and sacred masks from Banjul to Ziguinchor (160 km  driving time 4 hrs.)  GAMBIA-SENEGAL Gambia is renowned as a bird-watching destination. With an ornithological guide, we will discover different species of African birds in their habitat. Drive to the southern border whit Casamance region of Senegal. We will leave the main track to join a remote village. We have lunch in the village, prepared by a local family to enjoy the Senegalese gastronomy and improve local community economy. If we are lucky, in the afternoon masks leave the sacred forest to dance for an enthusiastic local crowd. Masks are part of the animistic Diola culture, people fear and respect masks, and consider them spirits who play an important role in solving conflicts between villagers. Evening arrival to our comfortable hotel on the banks of Casamance River. DAY 9: Sacred kings, Ziguinchor-Cap Skirring  Saly (150 km approx.  driving-time 4 hrs.-Fly to Dakar)  SENEGAL We will leave the main road to visit an adobe-fortified building still inhabited by a large patriarchal Diola family, an interesting example of traditional African sculptural architecture. These large clay and wooden fortified houses, where light comes from a central hole in the roof, are known as impluvium houses and had the function to protect their dwellers from outside attacks. In a hidden village, we will be received by the king of a Diola Kingdom. After the protocol salutations the king, that is also the high priest holding both political and mystical power, will answer our questions on the traditional rules in Diola society. Drive to the airport in Cap Skirring to board a spectacular flight to Dakar over river estuaries and the Atlantic coast. DAY 10: Dakar out  SENEGAL Assistance for last shopping. In the evening transfer to the airport for the flight out. Optional: Visit of the Bandia Reserve (4 hrs) Safari to the reserve of Bandia where you can meet all the big mammals of Africa in 3.500 ha of grand nature: huge baobabs, thorny bushes, whimsical lianas. VISAS: Senegal  not required for EU, USA, and Canada citizens (ask complete list). For other nationalities, a visa can be obtained at Dakar airport. If you apply for a visa upon arrival requires a double entry. Gambia: please, check; for most nationalities not needed or available at the border. VACCINATIONS: Yellow fever  compulsory; malaria prophylaxis  highly recommended; cholera not necessary at the moment but to be checked upon departure; covid vaccination card MEALS: lunch  restaurants (pre-selected menus) or cold picnic; dinner  at the hotel restaurant (pre-selected menus). LUGGAGE: please contain the weight in 20 kg (45 lb.). We suggest bringing mosquito repellent. TRAVEL INSURANCE: Not included. Mandatory for medical assistance, repatriation, material, and physical damages. We are not responsible for any material and physical damage during the tour TRANSPORT: on roads and tracks by Minibus or 44, domestic flight Capi Skirring  Dakar ACCOMMODATIONS: Hotels and lodges are always chosen with maximum care, however due to possible lack of availability in some hotels, the Tour Leader may have to replace some hotels during the tour itself with others of similar standard. In some hotels, single rooms are not always granted. All our trips are designed to be flexible so that we can adapt to external conditions and take advantage of opportunities that arise once there. Considering the special nature of the journey, some parts may be modified due to unpredictable factors and are based on unarguable decisions of our Tour Leader. Costs originating from such variations will be the sole responsibility of the participants. Of course, the Leader will do his/her utmost to adhere to the original program. Prices could change in case of major changes in services costs, beyond the organizers will. Included: Assistance at Dakar airport upon arrival and departure. Transfers and tour in a great variety of different transports, each fitting the different geographical environment, allowing maximum interaction with the local peoples, comfort, and fun: minibuses /microbuses, 4WD vehicles, local calash (private use), local bush taxi called taxi brousse (private use), donkey chariot, domestic flight Cap Skirring-Dakar Tour Leader (languages spoken English, French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese as available) Tours and visits as per the program. Accommodation in standard rooms/bungalows/permanent tents as per itinerary. All meals as described, from breakfast of day 2 to lunch of day 10. One bottle of Mineral water in the bus/car each day during the visits. Entrance fees to parks, concessions, protected areas, cultural sites, festivals, and events as in the program. First Aid box. All service charges and taxes. Not included: International flights Visa fees Covid tests if required Mineral water and drinks at restaurants and hotels Portage Fees for personal photos and videos Personal insurance (compulsory) Tips for drivers, guides, and hotel staff Any item of personal nature such as phone calls, laundry, etc. Whatever is not mentioned as included Share on Send an inquiry N of travelers1234567891010+ Departure Date By using this form you accept that the data requested in it is used in accordance with the "EC Regulation, European Parliament 27/04/2016 n 679, G.U. 04/05/2016" (GDPR). Hr finns de kilometerlnga strnderna mot Atlanten, hr finns flodturer lngs Gambia-floden, hr finns mycket sol ret om och hr finns det myllrande folklivet p marknaderna i huvudstaden Banjul. Du kan ocks boka till en rundresa i Gambia och Senegal, med natur, kultur och spnnande mten. P s vis fr du se och uppleva nnu mer under din resa till Gambia.Hotell p strandenOm du bokar din resa med Ving till Gambia har du en hel del att vlja mellan. Cape Point-omrdet passar dig som vill bo enkelt. Hr har du ocks nra till flera lokala marknader dr du kan fynda bland trsniderier, frukt och batiktyger. Vill du ha nnu mer lugn och ro under din resa freslr vi att du vljer ett hotell i Kotu- eller Bijilo-omrdet. Fr dig som fredrar att bo i hndelsernas centrum r omrdet Kololi och framfr allt Senegambia det bsta alternativet. Direkt utanfr hotellen, som vid Senegambia Beach, finns ett bra utbud av restauranger, barer och olika njen. Var du n vljer att bo kan du alltid hitta ett hotell till bra pris vid stranden, s du inte behver g lngt fr dagens frsta dopp.Avkoppling i GambiaEfter en lng dag p stranden r det sknt att dra sig upp mot hotellet fr att koppla av med en drink fre middagen. Vid den hr tiden p dygnet, precis fre den fantastiska solnedgngen, samlas turister och gambier p stranden fr att spela fotboll och strandvolleyboll. Utelivet r lugnt p de flesta hotell, men p de strre erbjuds ofta ngon form av underhllning. Missa till exempel inte de afrikanska dansuppvisningarna  en frgstark och suggestiv upplevelse, precis som Gambia i vrigt.Ls mer om GambiaLs mer om GambiaVra kunder om Gambia4,4/5Betyg frn Vings gster: 4.4/5Baseras p 90 svarBarnvnligt4,3Strnder4,2Restauranger & barer4,2Fler omdmenVra kunder om Gambia4,4/5Betyg frn Vings gster: 4.4/5Gstbetyget r resultatet av 90 gsters svar p frgan "Hur njd var du med resmlet som helhet?"Strnder4,2Restauranger & barer4,2Njesliv3,6Aktiviteter (se & gra)3,9Shopping3,6Barnvnligt4,3Hitta ditt hotellBra att vetaHotell p strandenPrisvrt boendeSolskertBra klimatKilometerlnga sandstrnderLokala restauranger StrnderStrnderna r flera kilometer lnga och 20-50 meter breda (ebb och flod). I allmnhet har de finkornig sand och r inte srskilt lnggrunda. P Atlantsidan kan vgorna vara stora och undervattensstrmmar frekommer. Vill man ta sig till en annan strand n den som ligger nrmast hotellet r det bst att resa med taxi eller jeep. De flesta hotell har privat strand och strax utanfr de mest populra hotellomrdena mter man milsvida strnder som dessutom r nst intill folktomma. Till skillnad mot vad mnga tror, och kanske ven i viss mn tidigare har upplevt, s ges faktiskt tillflle att f vara i fred under promenaden. Solen r mycket stark s hr nra ekvatorn och hg solskyddsfaktor rekommenderas. Var uppmrksam p understrmmarna i havet och g aldrig lngre ut n att du bottnar ordentligt. Simma aldrig ut i havet, simma utefter stranden i stllet. Vattenaktiviteter finns i mycket liten omfattning. D Gambia r ett muslimskt land br man visa respekt och inte sola topless vid stranden eller p hotellets poolomrde.P sndagarna och andra helgdagar frvandlas stranden till en mtesplats fr lokalbefolkningen, som d kommer hit med sina picknick-korgar och umgs. Vissa kvllar r pulsen hgre med livlig musik och dans.SanyangDen kanske finaste stranden i Gambia. Hr kan du avnjuta din mltid i lugn och ro p ngon av de lokala restaurangerna, till exempel Rainbow Bar. P kvllen samlas lokalbefolkningen fr grillfester. Sanyang ligger cirka 45 minuter med bil frn turistomrdena. Vgor och undervattensstrmmar r mycket sllsynta.Cape PointPopulr, vlbeskt strand belgen p nordspetsen av Cape Point dr vrt tidigare Sunwing lg. Det finns ingen matservering p stranden, men det finns ngra lokala kiosker p stranden som serverar dryck. Flera nrliggande hotell har restauranger. Var uppmrksam p undervattensstrmmar.Kotu strandVlbeskt strand utanfr hotellen Bungalow Beach, Kombo Beach och Sunset Beach. Lngs med stranden, som r flera kilometer lng, finns flera strandbarer som serverar svalkande drycker. Hlsa grna p de charmerande fruktdamerna som sljer fruktsallad nedanfr marknaden.Palmarima-strandenPopulr strand, speciellt under helgen d mnga kommer hit fr att promenera, spela fotboll eller bara slappa av. Festerna p sndagskvllar r ocks populra.PriserSolstolar r i regel gratis fr hotellets egna gster vid den privata hotellstranden. Om man vill tillbringa dagen p stranden vid ett annat hotell eller utanfr de privata hotellstrnderna fr man oftast betala en avgift.Mat, dryck och nattlivMat och dryckNattlivI Gambia finns gott om olika slags restauranger, matstllen och cafer som r utmrkta om du vill smaka landets egen mat. Prova grna de tv matrtter som betecknas som landets nationalrtter: Chicken Yassa, en kycklingrtt med en starkt kryddad ss (Yassa), och Domoda som r den vanligaste matrtten hos lokalbefolkningen. Den bestr av antingen kyckling, ktt eller fisk och serveras med ris och jordntsss. website_content.original_text: Information Tour Plan Location Gallery Wild Gambia: Best of Birding per person Join us on this exceptional birding tour in The Gambia, where youll be able to quickly pick up a huge number of species in just over a week. The Gambia has so much to offer, and this tour highlights the exceptional bird diversity of this beautiful country. Join us for an exceptional birding tour highlighting the best of Moroccos diverse bird species and extraordinary scenery. This meticulously curated tour allows you to explore Moroccos diversity of birdlife across different habitats and landscapes, ranging from the majestic Atlas Mountains to the vast Sahara Desert. Discover the rich avifauna this remarkable country offers. Bird count:Over 300 Speed:Relaxed Tour difficulty:Easy When to visit:The Gambia is fantastic for birding all year-round. However, the absolute prime birding season spans from November through March, coinciding with the high and dry period that typically persists until May. November offers the most favourable conditions for spotting the elusive Egyptian Plover, whose presence hinges on optimal water levels. While the weather remains characteristically warm, with March and April experiencing peak temperatures, the months of December and January provide a slight respite from the tropical heat. This seasonal window not only yields an influx of migratory species but also has the many resident species in their breeding plumage, creating a good photo opportunities and generally nice sightings. The confluence of these climatic factors transforms The Gambia into a birding paradise during this peak period and is such a joy. Price:Our tailor-made birding tours are custom-designed for each client, making standard pricing difficult. Costs vary based on factors like accommodation, group size, duration, and specific locations. For a personalised quote that matches your taste and budget, please contact us with your requirements. As an example, this Wild Gambia: Birding costs 2,800 per person, based on a group of 6 individuals staying in top-end mid-range safari lodges with shared twin rooms. For our Set Departure Birding Tours, with fixed prices, please click the button below. Tour Leader Ansu has been bird watching since attending school. He became involved fully in bird watching after high school and today he is one of the top bird guides in The Gambia. Ansus experience and competence in the field of bird watching has given him fame and has attracted the attention of the other Gambian bird guides. Ansu was born and raised in the countryside where bird life and nature in general is at its best. There is no doubt about Ansus experience and knowledge in the field of birding in The Gambia. This should be no surprise as Ansu has been, summer after summer, engaging in research and also involved in creating water holes to attract birds for photographic opportunities. One of these water holes he created is in Bulock forest where Green and Red-winged Pytilias and Black-faced Firefinch come to drink. Ansu is a senior member of research and development of The Gambia Birdwatchers Association. Ansus eagle-eyed, fast spotting, identification and his discoveries of rare birds in The Gambia has given him the award title PROFESSOR by his colleagues. This title is very well known in The Gambia. In 2010 February 14th, he was the first Gambian bird guide to see the Little Green Woodpecker in ABUKO NATURE RESERVE and this was the first record for The Gambia. In 2011, Ansu found Pels Fishing Owl in Bulock in his village and most amazingly, on land near the river. This was not confirmed until 2015. In 2013, his highlight was the White-crested Tiger Bittern (Tiger Heron). Ansu will never stop his magic of discovering rare birds in The Gambia. On the 2nd January 2015 he became the famous record breaker by spotting one of the most sought after birds in The Gambian bird list at Kotu Creek. This was the Finfoot and had only been seen upriver before.Ansu provides the opportunity for birders and non birders irrespective of experience to see rare and exotic birds in The Gambia and Senegal. Whether you are looking for an introduction to the birds of The Gambia or you are more experienced, Ansu can provide suitable opportunities so that you can return home with happy memories and, perhaps, visit The Gambia again. Ansu, the professor of bird guiding, will make your dreams come true leaving you with happy memories to take home. Northern Red Bishop Birding & Wildlife Highlights Blue-bellied RollerRed-chested SwallowWest African SwallowLavender WaxbillNorthern White-faced OwlWestern Red-billed HornbillBrown-necked Parrot (fuscicollis)Pied-winged SwallowLong-tailed Glossy StarlingWhite-crowned Robin-ChatGreater Blue-eared StarlingLesser Blue-eared StarlingBronze-tailed StarlingPurple StarlingSplendid SunbirdVariable SunbirdCopper SunbirdNorthern Grey-headed SparrowWhite-billed Buffalo WeaverYellow-crowned BishopBlack-winged Red BishopNorthern Red BishopBronze MannikinAfrican SilverbillOrange-cheeked WaxbillGrey-headed BushshrikeBlack-crowned TchagraNorthern PuffbackYellow-crowned GonolekRed-shouldered Cuckooshrike The Gambia Departure Banjul Included Airport Transfers Birding Telescope Full board (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner) Mineral Water National Park Fees Overnight In Top Safari Lodges Professional Bird Guide Professional Driver Safari Vehicle Updated Bird Checklist WiFi Our gallery A few photos from our previous birding tours in The Gambia 1 Day 1: Arrival at Banjul Arrival at Banjul International Airport and private transfer to your hotel. 2 Day 2: Kotu Creek After breakfast, we'll transfer to Kotu Creek for a full day of birding including a boat trip into the creek. Expect a high count of species! 3 Day 3: Farasutu & Pirang Forest After breakfast, we'll drive to Farasutu Forest for a morning birding session. We'll then drive to the nearby Pirang Forest for an afternoon session, then drive back to the hotel. 4 Day 4: Kartong Sand Mine & Gunjur Forest After an early breakfast pickup at 7 am, we'll drive to Kartong Sand Mine for some exceptional birding and then in the afternoon we'll be visiting Gunjur Forest, where we can expect many targets. At 5 pm, we will drive back to the hotel. 5 Day 5: Tendaba Camp After an early breakfast we'll drive to the south bank road to Tendaba Camp, where we will be visiting key birding hotspots along the south road. We will reach Tendaba Camp at 7 pm, check into our rooms, and prepare for dinner at 8 pm. 6 Day 6: Kisse & Tunku Bolong After breakfast, we will be taking a three-hour boat trip to explore Kisse and Tunku Bolong. After the boat trip, we will explore the woods of Tendaba village and the Bateling track for the whole day, then head back to the coast. 7 Day 7: Marakissa River Camp Today, we'll be spending the whole day at Marakissa River Camp looking for specials and target species. 8 Day 8: Departure day We'll spend our last day looking for any species we might have missed and then in the afternoon, you'll be transferred to the airport for your international flight back home. TOUR LOCATION Banjul, Kotu Creek, Farasutu, Pirang Forest, Kartong Sand Mine, Gunjur Forest, Tendaba Camp, Kisse, Tunku Bolong & Marakissa River Camp

website_content.original_text: Abuko Rainforest Reserve Abuko Forest Reserve is home to gorgeous birds like the startlingly-coloured violet and Guinea turacos, and some deceptively dozy-looking crocodiles. The tall trees here with their superb buttress roots are worth seeing in their own right, as are the reserve's rare western red colobus. Find Out More Where: West Africa Ideal for viewing: western red colobus, green monkey, violet turaco, blue-bellied roller, West African crocodile Excellent for: Birdwatching , Kiang West National Park The park is an important area for Gambian wildlife, as most of the country's remaining mammals are found here, including Cape clawless otter, Guinea baboon, bushbuck and caracal. Over 300 bird species and many interesting species of reptile have also been recorded in the park. Find Out More Where: Southern Gambia Ideal for viewing: blue-breasted kingfisher, African blue flycatcher, white-backed night-heron, giant kingfisher, Guinea baboon Excellent for: Birdwatching , View trips to these locations West African Birdwatch Join us for some superb tropical birding  including parrots, hornbills, rollers, bee-eaters, sunbirds, kingfishers and more than a dozen herons  all just six hours from the UK. The Gambia offers a fantastic variety of habitats and their birds within just a few miles of the river. Find out more about West African Birdwatch Price (inc. flights): 12 days from 3,295 Trip type: Group Tour When to go: J F M A M J J A S O N D Seasons Dry Season Nov to May: The dry season runs each year typically from November to May, and temperatures are less intense in coastal regions. Rainy Season Jun to Oct: The Gambia has a tropical climate, with the rainy season falling between June and mid-October each year. Wildlife events Nov to Feb: European migrants arrive for winter

website_content.original_text: Reisetermin whlen 28.10.25 - 17.11.25 (21 Tage) Senegal und Gambia Auf Entdeckungstour in Senegambia 21 Tage  3.299,- * * terminspezifischer Preis Teilnehmer: min. 6  max. 16 Reise buchen Download Reisebeschreibung Persnliche Beratung 02203 9255700 Mo.-Fr. 9:30-17:30 Uhr E-Mail Senegal und Gambia Auf Entdeckungstour in Senegambia Highlights der Rundreise Besichtigung der UNESCO-Welterbesttte Insel Gore Besichtigung der kolonialen Altstadt von Saint Louis mit der PferdekutscheBootsfahrten im Djoudj-Nationalpark, im Gambia-Fluss-Delta und im Sine-Saloum-Deltatropisch-grne CasamanceKultur erleben: Maskentanz der Diola in Coubalanschne Strnde bei Cap Skirring Erlebe das ganze Abenteuer Westafrikas! Auf der Zweilndertour erwarten dich auergewhnliche Landschaften von Nord nach Sd. Immer wieder begegnen wir herzlichen Menschen und ihrer Kultur, wir lernen hautnah die noch lebendige Kultur der Diola kennen beim Maskentanz in Coubalan und besuchen ihre Drfer in der schnen Casamance im Sden des Senegals. Mit einer Piroge schippern wir durch den vogelreichen Djoudj-Nationalpark und erleben die Mangrovenlandschaft des Sine-Saloum-Deltas. Wir besuchen in Saint Louis das wuselige Fischerviertel Guet Ndar, erkunden die Stadt in der Pferdekutsche, genieen das lockere Flair von Gambias Hauptstadt Banjul und erkunden das Gambia-Fluss-Delta mit dem Boot, mit seinen tropisch-grnen Uferwldern und der ehemaligen Sklaveninsel James Island. An den schnen Kstenabschnitten von Cap Skirring und der Petite Cte whnen wir uns im Paradies und erholen uns von erlebnisreichen Tagen. Reiseverlauf  Tag fr Tag Alle ffnen Tag 1  Di., 28.10.2025 Flug nach Dakar  Saly Flug nach Dakar; Weiterfahrt nach Saly Bienvenue au Sngal Mit der Bahn erreichst du innerhalb Deutschlands kostenfrei und umweltfreundlich deinen Abflughafen. Unser Flug bringt uns von Frankfurt nach Dakar. Dort empfngt uns unsere WORLD INSIGHT-Reiseleitung am Flughafen. Ein etwa einstndiger Transfer bringt uns zu unserer Unterkunft in Saly. Der ideale Ort fr einen entspannten Beginn der Reise durch diese beiden aufregenden Lnder  fernab vom Grostadttrubel. Wir checken in unserem Strandhotel an der Petite Cte ein. Fahrstrecke: 30 km bernachtung: Les Bougainvilles*** od. Saly Princesse **(*) in SalyMahlzeiten: gem Bordservice Tag 2  Mi., 29.10.2025 Saly  Joal-Fadiouth  Mbour  Saly Besuch von Joal-Fadiouth und Besuch des Fischmarktes von Mbour Muschelinsel Joal-Fadiouth und Fischmarkt in Mbour Den Morgen lassen wir erst einmal ruhig angehen, bevor wir zu unserer ersten Erkundungstour aufbrechen. In etwa zweieinhalb Stunden fahren wir zur vertrumten Muschelinsel Joal-Fadiouth, ein wundervolles Beispiel fr das friedliche Miteinander der verschiedenen Religionen Senegals. Hoch oben auf dem Muschelberg befindet sich ein Friedhof, auf dem sowohl Christen als auch Muslime beerdigt werden. Unser Ziel fr den frhen Nachmittag ist die Stadt Mbour. Am Strand erwartet uns hier das bunte Treiben des Fischmarktes, und wir bestaunen die unzhligen, farbenfroh bemalten Pirogen. Am spten Nachmittag kehren wir nach Saly zurck, wo wir den Tag in unserem Strandhotel ausklingen lassen. Fahrstrecke: 50 km bernachtung: Les Bougainvilles*** od. Saly Princesse **(*) in SalyMahlzeiten: F Tag 3  Do., 30.10.2025 Saly  Rufisque  Lac Rose  Dakar Besuch einer Schildkrtenaufzuchtstation in Rufisque und des Rosa Sees, Fahrt in den Dnen Rosa See und Stopp in einem Artenschutz-Projekt fr Schildkrten Wir fahren heute ber Rufisque und den Salzsee Lac Rose in die Hauptstadt Dakar. In der Grostadt Rufisque vertreten wir uns bei einem Spaziergang durch die Altstadt die Beine. Danach besuchen wir ein "Schildkrtendorf"  ein Artenschutzprojekt, bei dem sich Wissenschaftler und Freiwillige fr den Schutz der grten Landschildkrtenart Afrikas einsetzen. Schlielich erreichen wir den Salzsee. Leider hat der berhmte Rosa See vor Kurzem durch gravierende berschwemmungen seine rosa Farbe verloren, und der Salzgehalt ist inzwischen so gering, dass auch die Salzbauern kaum noch Salz aus dem See gewinnen knnen. In den kommenden Jahren wird sich zeigen, ob der See sein kologisches Gleichgewicht wiederherstellen kann. Wir spazieren etwas am Ufer des Sees entlang und erkunden die Umgebung zusammen mit unserer Reiseleitung. Auerdem unternehmen wir einen Ausflug in die Dnen, den wir auf den Pritschen eines alten Militrfahrzeugs unternehmen. Am Abend erreichen wir unsere Unterkunft in der Hauptstadt Dakar. Fahrstrecke: 100 km bernachtung: Casa Mara*** in DakarMahlzeiten: F Tag 4  Fr., 31.10.2025 Dakar  Insel Gore  Dakar Stadterkundung in Dakar, Ausflug zur Sklaveninsel Gore Pulsierende Hauptstadt Wir beginnen den Tag mit dem Besuch des Krutermarktes Tilne und lassen die vielen Farben und Gerche auf uns wirken. Nach einem Abstecher in die Medina, wo wir der Volksgruppe der Lebou begegnen, geht es mittags auf die Fhre zur ehemaligen Sklaveninsel Gore (UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe), die wir nach einer halben Stunde erreichen. Auf unserem rund zweistndigen Rundgang durch die malerischen Gassen besuchen wir auch das Sklavenhaus "Maison des Esclaves" aus dem 18. Jahrhundert mit seinem berchtigten Treppenaufgang, der die Sklaven von ihren Peinigern und der "Tr ohne Wiederkehr" trennte. Vom Kastell aus berblicken wir dann die Insel und die Skyline von Dakar. Zurck in der Hauptstadt besichtigen wir am Nachmittag das pompse "Monument de la Renaissance Africaine". Fahrstrecke: 30 km bernachtung: Casa Mara*** in DakarMahlzeiten: F Tag 5  Sa., 01.11.2025 Dakar Besuch des Fischmarktes und weitere Stadterkundungen, Besuch des Museums der schwarzen Zivilisationen, nachmittags Freizeit Mrkte, Museen und Geschichte Am Vormittag besuchen wir den Fischmarkt Soumbdioune. Bei einer Stadtrundfahrt sehen wir den berhmten Kermel-Markt, die Nationalversammlung und den alten kolonialen Bahnhof. ber den Unabhngigkeitsplatz erreichen wir den Prsidentenpalast. Anschlieend nehmen wir uns Zeit, das Muse des civilisations noires in Dakar zu besichtigen. Das ethnologische und knstlerische Museum ist der schwarzen Zivilisation gewidmet: Das Themenspektrum reicht von den ersten Spuren menschlichen Lebens bis zur zeitgenssischen Kunst. Der Nachmittag steht dir frei zur Verfgung, entweder fr eigene Stadterkundungen oder fr einen entspannten Abschluss des Tages im Hotel. Fahrstrecke: 30 km bernachtung: Casa Mara*** in DakarMahlzeiten: F Tag 6  So., 02.11.2025 Dakar  Saint Louis Fahrt nach Saint Louis mit Stopp in This mit Besuchen einer Kunstaustellung und des Marktes, weiterer Stopp in der Kommune Mkh, Fischerviertel in Saint Louis Auf dem Weg in die alte Hauptstadt Heute brechen wir auf in die alte Hauptstadt Saint Louis mit ihrem kolonialen Erbe. Sie war bis 1902 Hauptstadt von Franzsisch-Westafrika. Nach etwa zwei Stunden Fahrt erreichen wir die Stadt This. Hier besuchen wir eine kleine Kunstausstellung und schlendern gemeinsam ber den bunten Markt. Einen weiteren Stopp legen wir in der Kommune Ngaye Mkh ein, wo die Mglichkeit besteht gemeinsam zu Mittag zu essen einen Schuhmacher besuchen, der uns sein Handwerk zeigt. Danach sind wir noch ca. drei Stunden mit dem Bus unterwegs, bis wir schlielich Saint Louis erreichen. Im Fischerviertel Guet Ndar in Saint Louis, mit Hunderten von bunten Pirogen und seinen Trockenfischstationen, erhaschen wir einen Eindruck vom Leben an der Atlantikkste und beziehen schlielich ein Hotel im kolonialen Zentrum der Stadt. Fahrstrecke: 265 km bernachtung: Hotel de la Poste** in Saint-Louis Mahlzeiten: F, M Tag 7  Mo., 03.11.2025 Saint Louis  Djoudj Nationalpark  Saint Louis Halbtagesausflug mit Pirogenfahrt und Vogelbeobachtung, anschlieend Stadterkundung mit der Pferdekutsche Pirogenfahrt im Vogelparadies und koloniales Flair Frh morgens fahren wir in die Steppen- und Buschsavannen Nordsenegals. Unser Ziel ist der Nationalpark Djoudj im Delta des Senegal-Flusses. Mit motorisierten Pirogen erkunden wir rund zwei Stunden das weltweit drittgrte Vogelschutzgebiet und Weltnaturerbe der UNESCO. Im grnen Paradies Djoudj sehen wir neben zahlreichen einheimischen Arten, wie Flamingos und Pelikanen, auch viele Zugvgel aus Europa, die hier von November bis Mrz berwintern (Fernglser nicht vergessen). Auf der Rckfahrt nach Saint-Louis statten wir den Peul-Bauern der Region noch einen Besuch ab. Bei der Rckkehr in Saint Louis warten die Pferdekutschen auf uns, mit denen wir das historische Zentrum mit seinen alten Kolonialbauten erkunden wollen (UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe). Fahrstrecke: 60 km bernachtung: Hotel de la Poste** in Saint-Louis Mahlzeiten: F Tag 8  Di., 04.11.2025 Saint Louis  Touba  Kaolack Moscheebesuch in Touba Die Heilige Stadt der Mouriden Unser Weg fhrt uns weiter in den Sden des Senegals. Wir teilen uns die lange Fahrt in zwei Etappen auf und nehmen ein paar Sehenswrdigkeiten entlang des Weges mit. Unterwegs machen wir Halt in der Stadt Touba, dem Zentrum der Mouriden, wo wir eine der grten Moscheen im westlichen Afrika betreten knnen (nur auerhalb der Gebetsstunden). Die Stadt Kaolack am Saloum-Fluss gelegen ist unser heutiges Ziel fr die bernachtung. Fahrstrecke: 290 km bernachtung: Relais Kaolack**(*) in KaolackMahlzeiten: F Tag 9  Mi., 05.11.2025 Kaolack  Coubalan Durchquerung Gambia und Flussberquerung, Diola-Kultur: Maskentanz von Coubalan Zu Besuch bei den Diola, Maskentanz von Coubalan Unser heutiges Ziel: die tropisch-grne Casamance und das Dorf Coubalan. Um einen weiten Umweg zu vermeiden, durchqueren wir heute die kleine Enklave Gambia. Die beiden Grenzbertritte werden zu einem Abenteuer fr sich. Keine Sorge, unser Reiseleiter kennt sich mit dem Papierkram aus. Schlielich berqueren wir den mchtigen Gambia-Fluss - Namensgeber des Landes, das wir im Verlauf der Reise noch genauer kennenlernen werden. Danach dauert es noch etwa 4 Stunden bis zu unserem heutigen Ziel: das Dorf Coubalan in der Casamance. Hier leben die Diola immer noch eng verbunden mit der Natur und ihrem kulturellen Erbe. Wir nchtigen mitten im Dorf in einem sehr einfachen Campement, dafr erleben wir am heutigen Abend etwas ganz Besonderes: den Maskentanz der Ethnie, bei dem sich die Tnzer mit aufwendig angefertigten Kostmen schmcken, begleitet von rhythmischer Musik und Gesang. Die Dorfgemeinschaft bereitet heute unser Abendessen zu. Es ist der Auftakt einiger weiterer Tage, an denen wir die Kultur der Casamance nher kennenlernen werden. Fahrstrecke: 250 km bernachtung: Campement Coubalang in CoubalanMahlzeiten: F, A Tag 10  Do., 06.11.2025 Coubalan  Cap Skirring Dorfspaziergnge in Coubalan und Kathioune, Kennenlernen der traditionellen Architektur und Lebensweise der Diola Mchtige Kapokbume Bei einem Rundgang durch das Dorf Coubalan treffen wir mit etwas Glck den Dorfchef und lassen uns die riesigen Kapokbume mit ihren mchtigen Brettwurzeln zeigen, die im Dorf zu finden sind. Auf dem Weg nach Cap Skirring besuchen wir das Dorf Kathioune, wo uns ein ortskundiger Dorfbewohner den Brunnen und einen heiligen Baum zeigt. In der Casamance ist der Animismus noch weit verbreitet, und in vielen Drfern finden sich heilige Sttten. Weiter geht's nach nach Oussouye, wo wir eine Kooperative behinderter Frauen treffen, die im Kunsthandwerk ttig sind. Mit etwas Glck begegnen wir in Oussouye dem einzigen verbleibenden traditionellen Herrscher der Diola-Ethnie, dem "Mane", der uns vom Leben der bemerkenswerten Solidargemeinschaft erzhlt. In Mlomp lernen wir die auergewhnliche Bauweise der Region kennen und besuchen ein doppelstckiges Lehmhaus. Am frhen Abend erreichen wir den schnsten Strandabschnitt Senegals bei Cap Skirring. Fahrstrecke: 150 km bernachtung: Campement No Stress** oder Hotel Maya** bei Cap SkirringMahlzeiten: F Tag 11  Fr., 07.11.2025 Cap Skirring Badetag am Strand von Cap Skirring od. eigene Erkundungen Tiefenentspannt am Strand Freue dich auf einen perfekten Badetag an den wunderschnen Strnden von Cap Skirring, die fr ihre lange, weiche Sandkste und die kristallklaren, warmen Gewsser bekannt sind. Diese Strnde bieten die ideale Umgebung, um eine Pause einzulegen, die Seele baumeln zu lassen und unter einer Palme liegend ein Buch am Strand zu lesen. Nutze die Zeit und teile dir deinen Tag ganz nach deinen Wnsche ein. Ausschlafen, ein Strandspaziergang oder ein erfrischendes Bad  vieles ist heute mglich. Wer die Gelegenheit nutzen mchte ins nahegelegene Stdtchen Cap Skirring zu fahren, nimmt sich ein Taxi, um etwas alltgliches Leben in der Stadt zu erhaschen. Fahrstrecke: - bernachtung: Campement No Stress** oder Hotel Maya** bei Cap SkirringMahlzeiten: F Tag 12  Sa., 08.11.2025 Cap Skirring  Ziguinchor Freilichtmuseum Sangawatt, Heiliges Tam-Tam in Siganar, Besuch des Impluvium-Haus in Enampore Eintauchen in die Diola-Kultur Heute Morgen besuchen wir das traditionelle Freilichtmuseum von Sangawatt, das der Kultur und den animistischen Traditionen der Diola gewidmet ist. Der Museumsleiter fhrt uns in die Geschichte und Lebensweise dieser ethnischen Gruppe ein und macht uns mit der animistischen Religion vertraut. Anschlieend fahren in Richtung Ziguinchor. Zunchst bestaunen wir in Siganar noch das heilige Tam-Tam des Dorfes, ein traditionelles Verstndigungsinstrument zwischen den Dorfbewohnern und den angrenzenden Drfern. Danach besichtigen wir das Impluvium-Haus in Enampore und erreichen am spten Nachmittag unser heutiges Ziel. Ziguinchor, das Handelszentrum der Casamance, besticht noch heute durch sein koloniales Flair. Unsere zentral gelegene Unterkunft lsst dem Unternehmungslustigen noch die Mglichkeit die Stadt in den Abendstunden auf eigene Faust zu erkunden oder zum Abendessen auszugehen. Ansonsten verfgt das Hotel ber einen kleinen, gemtlichen Innenhof, der zum Verweilen einldt. Vielleicht hast du Lust auf einen Sprung in den Pool! Fahrstrecke: 190 km bernachtung: Le Flamboyant** in ZiguinchorMahlzeiten: F Tag 13  So., 09.11.2025 Ziguinchor  Kassagne Grenzberquerung nach Gambia, gefhrter Spaziergang oder Radtour Natur pur am Gambia-Fluss Nach etwa 90 Kilometern berqueren wir die Grenze nach Gambia. Das kleine Land wird vollstndig vom Senegal umschlossen und wurde einst von Grobritannien kolonialisiert. Am Mittag erreichen wir unsere traumhaft an einem Zufluss des Gambia-Fluss gelegene Unterkunft in Kassagne und haben ein wenig Zeit fr uns. Am Nachmittag erleben wir auf unserem gefhrten leichten Spaziergang oder einer kurzen und leichten Radtour auf Mountainbikes die Natur und Drfer entlang des mchtigen Flusses. Fahrstrecke: 120 km bernachtung: AbCa's Creek Lodge*** in KassagneMahlzeiten: F Tag 14  Mo., 10.11.2025 Kassagne Bootstour auf dem Gambia-Fluss, nachmittags Freizeit Unterwegs auf dem Gambia-Fluss Der Gambiafluss und seine Nebenflsse schlngeln sich majesttisch durch die malerische Landschaft Westafrikas und bietet eine schne Kulisse fr unsere Tage in der kleinen Enklave Gambia. Auf unserer heutigen Bootstour halten wir Ausschau nach den bunten Vogelarten und begegnen vielleicht einigen neugierigen Affen, die hier in den Mangroven beheimatet sind. Die zweite Tageshlfte verbringen wir dann in der entspannten Atmosphre der Lodge direkt am Flussufer und gnnen uns eine Auszeit. Fahrstrecke: - bernachtung: AbCa's Creek Lodge*** in KassagneMahlzeiten: F Tag 15  Di., 11.11.2025 Kassagne  Banjul Spaziergang im Makasutu Cultural Forest, Affenwald, nachmittags Freizeit am Atlantik Besuch im Affenwald Ein bis zwei Stunden fahren wir ber staubige Pisten entlang des Gambia-Flusses in westliche Richtung. Sdlich von Banjul stoppen wir noch im Makasutu Cultural Forest, wo wir bei einem Spaziergang die Flora und Fauna des Naturschutzgebietes bestaunen und ein einfaches Mittagessen einnehmen werden. Auf unserer Weiterfahrt stoppen wir im Affenwald von Bijilo, dessen Bewohner uns frech begren. In unmittelbarer Nachbarschaft liegt unser Hotel in der Nhe des Strandes in einem der Vororte von Banjul. Es bleibt noch Zeit fr ein Bad im Atlantik. Fahrstrecke: 90 km bernachtung: Mansea Beach** oder Cape Point** bei BanjulMahlzeiten: F, M Tag 16  Mi., 12.11.2025 Banjul Stadterkundung und Marktbesuch Das kulturelle Herz Gambias Freue dich auf eine kulturhistorische Erkundung! Banjul ist berschaubar, und die Sehenswrdigkeiten sind zu Fu erreichbar. Wir spazieren durch das Zentrum der Stadt, vorbei am July 22nd Square, entlang der Hauptgeschftsstrae Liberation Avenue bis hin zum berhmten Albert Market. Unterwegs steigen wir die Treppen zum Triumphbogen Arch 22 hinauf, von dem aus wir einen guten Ausblick ber die Stadt haben. Anschlieend besichtigen wir die Jamah-Moschee und das kleine Nationalmuseum. Danach geht es zum Markt der Stadt. Wir schlendern durch die engen Gassen und erkunden die bunten Stnde mit einer Vielzahl von Waren, darunter handgefertigte Kunsthandwerksprodukte, lokale Textilien, Gewrze, frisches Obst und Gemse sowie traditionelle afrikanische Kleidung. Den Tag lassen wir am Abend in unserem Hotel am Atlantik ausklingen. Fahrstrecke: 50 km bernachtung: Mansea Beach** oder Cape Point** bei BanjulMahlzeiten: F Tag 17  Do., 13.11.2025 Banjul  James Island  Toubakouta Fhrfahrt ber den Gambia-Fluss, Besuch von James Island, Grenzberquerung in den Senegal Transatlantischer Sklavenhandel Zunchst fahren wir nach Banjul und und nehmen die Fhre ber den Gambia-Fluss nach Barra und fahren flussaufwrts weiter zu einem kleinen Bootsanleger. Von hier setzen wir mit einem Passagierboot nach James Island ber, eine Insel im Herzen des Gambia-Flusses. Hier tauchen wir ein in die faszinierende Vergangenheit dieses UNESCO-Weltkulturerbes. Als bedeutender Handelsposten whrend der Zeit des transatlantischen Sklavenhandels diente die Insel als Knotenpunkt fr den Austausch von Waren und Menschen. Wir erkunden die gut erhaltenen Ruinen und erfahren mehr ber die dunklen Kapitel der Geschichte, whrend wir durch die ehemaligen Festungsanlagen und Sklavenzellen wandern. Gleichzeitig genieen wir die malerische Schnheit der umliegenden Flusslandschaft und lassen uns von der Bedeutung und Komplexitt dieses historischen Ortes beeindrucken. Zurck an Land, fahren wir mit unserem Bus ber die Grenze in Karang weiter nach Toubakouta. Zurck im Senegal erreichen wir am Nachmittag die Mangrovenlandschaft des Sine-Saloum-Deltas. Seit 2011 gehrt der Nationalpark mit seinen vielen kleinen Inseln und Wasserarmen zum Weltnaturerbe der UNESCO. Unsere Unterkunft liegt direkt am Wasser, und nach der langen Busfahrt finden wir am Pool ein wenig Ruhe und Erholung. Fahrstrecke 125 km bernachtung: Keur Saloum**(*) bei Toubakouta im Sine-Saloum-DeltaMahlzeiten: F Tag 18  Fr., 14.11.2025 Sine-Saloum-Delta Kennenlernen der Palmweinernte und der nachhaltigen Austernfischerei, Erkundung des Sine-Saloum-Deltas mit Pirogen Die Geister der Serer und Mandinka Heute erhalten wir mitten im Busch einen Einblick in die Palmweinernte, wobei geschickte Erntehelfer auf halsbrecherische Art bis in die Baumgipfel klettern, um den Palmwein in Flaschen zu sammeln. Im Dorf Sangako begegnen wir Frauen einer Kooperative, die uns nach einem kurzen Spaziergang zu den Mangroven etwas zur kologisch nachhaltigen Austernfischerei erzhlen. Auerdem erkunden wir an Bord einer Piroge die Schnheit des Sine-Saloum-Deltas mit seinen Lagunen, kleinen Inseln, mchtigen Baobabs und Mangrovenwldern. Wir schippern durch diese friedliche und naturbelassene Welt und erfreuen uns an den zahlreichen Vgeln, die hier zu Hause sind. Wir entdecken dann eine kleine Muschelinsel, auf der die Verstorbenen der Serer und Mandinka beerdigt wurden (ihre Geister soll es noch heute hier geben). Geniee traumhafte Ausblicke, bevor wir mit der Piroge die kleinen Seitenarme des Deltas erkunden und mit etwas Glck Vgel wie Pelikane, Eisvgel, Bienenfresser, Webervgel und Rothalsfalken beobachten knnen. Gemeinsam mit ihnen haben wir unsere abwechslungsreiche Senegal und Gambia Reise bis ins Detail geplant, denn sie sind unsere Experten vor Ort. website_content.translated_text: Select travel date 28.10.25 - 17.11.25 (21 days) Senegal and Gambia On a discovery tour in Senegambia 21 days  3,299 * * date-specific price Participants: min. 6 - max. 16 Book trip Download travel description Personal advice 02203 9255700 Mon.-Fri. 9:30 a.m. - 5:30 p.m. E-mail Senegal and Gambia On a discovery tour in Senegambia Highlights of the round trip Visit to the UNESCO World Heritage Island of Gore Tour of the colonial old town of Saint Louis by horse-drawn carriage Boat trips in the Djoudj National Park, the Gambia River Delta and the Sine-Saloum Delta Experience the tropical green Casamance culture: masked dance of the Diola in Coubalan Beautiful beaches at Cap Skirring Experience the whole adventure of West Africa! On this two-country tour, you'll experience extraordinary landscapes from north to south. We'll repeatedly encounter warm-hearted people and their cultures; we'll experience the vibrant culture of the Diola people up close during the masked dance in Coubalan and visit their villages in the beautiful Casamance region in southern Senegal. We'll sail through the bird-rich Djoudj National Park in a pirogue and experience the mangrove landscape of the Sine-Saloum Delta. We'll visit the bustling fishing district of Guet Ndar in Saint Louis, explore the city by horse-drawn carriage, enjoy the relaxed atmosphere of Gambia's capital, Banjul, and explore the Gambia River Delta by boat, with its tropical green riparian forests and the former slave island of James Island. On the beautiful coastal stretches of Cap Skirring and the Petite Cte, we'll feel like we're in paradise and recover from our eventful days. Itinerary  Day by Day Open all Day 1  Tue., October 28, 2025 Flight to Dakar  Saly Flight to Dakar; onward journey to Saly "Bienvenue au Sngal" From within Germany, you can reach your departure airport free of charge and in an environmentally friendly way. Our flight takes us from Frankfurt to Dakar. Our WORLD INSIGHT tour guide will meet us at the airport. A roughly one-hour transfer takes us to our accommodation in Saly. The ideal place for a relaxing start to our journey through these two exciting countries  far from the hustle and bustle of the big city. We check into our beach hotel on the Petite Cte. Distance: 30 km Overnight: Les Bougainvilles*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: according to onboard service Day 2  Wed., October 29, 2025 Saly  Joal-Fadiouth  Mbour  Saly Visit to Joal-Fadiouth and the Mbour fish market Shell Island, Joal-Fadiouth, and Fish Market in Mbour We'll start the morning off gently before setting off on our first exploration. In about two and a half hours, we'll drive to the idyllic shell island of Joal-Fadiouth, a wonderful example of the peaceful coexistence of Senegal's different religions. High up on the shell mountain is a cemetery where both Christians and Muslims are buried. Our destination for the early afternoon is the town of Mbour. The hustle and bustle of the fish market awaits us on the beach, and we marvel at the countless, brightly painted pirogues. In the late afternoon, we return to Saly, where we end the day at our beach hotel. Distance: 50 km Overnight: Les Bougainvilles*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: B Day 3  Thursday, October 30, 2025 Saly  Rufisque  Lac Rose  Dakar Visit a turtle breeding station in Rufisque and the Pink Lake, drive through the dunes of the Pink Lake, and stop at a turtle conservation project. Today, we travel via Rufisque and the salt lake Lac Rose to the capital, Dakar. In the city of Rufisque, we stretch our legs with a walk through the old town. Afterwards, we visit a "turtle village"  a conservation project where scientists and volunteers work to protect Africa's largest tortoise species. Finally, we reach the salt lake. Unfortunately, the famous Pink Lake recently lost its pink color due to severe flooding, and its salt content is now so low that even salt farmers can barely extract salt from the lake. The coming years will show whether the lake can restore its ecological balance. We'll take a short walk along the lake's shore and explore the surrounding area with our guide. We'll also take a trip to the dunes, which we'll do on the back of an old military vehicle. In the evening, we'll reach our accommodation in the capital, Dakar. Distance: 100 km Overnight: Casa Mara*** in Dakar Meals: B Day 4 - Fri., October 31, 2025 Dakar - Gore Island - Dakar City tour in Dakar, excursion to the slave island of Gore Vibrant capital We begin the day with a visit to the Tilne herb market and take in the many colors and smells. After a detour to the medina, where we meet the Lebou ethnic group, we board the ferry at midday to the former slave island of Gore (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), which we reach after half an hour. On our approximately two-hour tour through the picturesque alleys, we also visit the 18th-century slave house "Maison des Esclaves" with its infamous staircase that separated the slaves from their tormentors and the "Door of No Return." From the castle, we then overlook the island and the skyline of Dakar. Back in the capital, we visit the pompous "Monument de la Renaissance Africanine" in the afternoon. Distance: 30 km Overnight: Casa Mara*** in Dakar Meals: B Day 5  Sat., November 1, 2025 Dakar Visit to the fish market and further city explorations, visit to the Museum of Black Civilizations, afternoon free time Markets, museums, and history In the morning, we visit the Soumbdioune fish market. On a city tour, we see the famous Kermel market, the National Assembly, and the old colonial train station. We reach the Presidential Palace via Independence Square. Afterwards, we take time to visit the Muse des Civilisations Noires in Dakar. This ethnological and art museum is dedicated to Black civilization: The topics range from the earliest traces of human life to contemporary art. The afternoon is at your leisure, either for exploring the city on your own or for a relaxing end to the day at the hotel. Distance: 30 km Overnight stay: Casa Mara*** in Dakar Meals: B Day 6 - Sun., November 2, 2025 Dakar - Saint Louis Drive to Saint Louis with a stop in This to visit an art exhibition and the market, further stop in the Mkh commune, the fishing district in Saint Louis On the way to the old capital Today we set off for the old capital Saint Louis with its colonial heritage. It was the capital of French West Africa until 1902. After about a two-hour drive, we reach the city of This. Here we visit a small art exhibition and stroll through the colorful market together. We make another stop in the Ngaye Mkh commune, where we have the opportunity to have lunch together and visit a shoemaker who will demonstrate his craft. After that, we will travel for about another three hours by bus until we finally reach Saint Louis. In the fishing district of Guet Ndar in Saint-Louis, with its hundreds of colorful pirogues and its dried-fish stations, we'll get a glimpse of life on the Atlantic coast before settling into a hotel in the colonial center of the city. Distance: 265 km Overnight: Hotel de la Poste** in Saint-Louis Meals: B, L Day 7  Mon., November 3, 2025 Saint-Louis  Djoudj National Park  Saint-Louis Half-day excursion with pirogue ride and birdwatching, followed by a horse-drawn carriage tour of the city. Pirogue ride in a bird paradise and colonial flair. Early in the morning, we travel into the steppes and bush savannahs of northern Senegal. Our destination is Djoudj National Park in the Senegal River Delta. We'll explore the world's third-largest bird sanctuary and a UNESCO World Heritage Site for around two hours by motorized pirogue. In the "green paradise of Djoudj," we will see numerous native species, such as flamingos and pelicans, as well as many migratory birds from Europe that winter here from November to March (don't forget your binoculars). On the return journey to Saint-Louis, we will pay a visit to the region's Peul farmers. Upon our return to Saint-Louis, horse-drawn carriages await us for our exploration of the historic center with its old colonial buildings (a UNESCO World Heritage Site). Distance: 60 km Overnight: Hotel de la Poste** in Saint-Louis Meals: Breakfast Day 8 - Tuesday, November 4, 2025 Saint Louis - Touba - Kaolack Mosque visit in Touba The "Holy City" of the Mourides Our journey continues into the south of Senegal. We will divide the long journey into two stages and take in a few sights along the way. On the way, we stop in the town of Touba, the center of the Mourides, where we can enter one of the largest mosques in West Africa (only outside of prayer hours). The town of Kaolack, located on the Saloum River, is our overnight destination. Distance: 290 km. Overnight: Relais Kaolack**(*) in Kaolack. Meals: B. Day 9  Wed., November 5, 2025. Kaolack  Coubalan. Crossing Gambia and river crossing, Diola culture: Mask dance of Coubalan. Visiting the Diola, mask dance of Coubalan. Our destination today: the tropically green Casamance and the village of Coubalan. To avoid a long detour, we will cross the small enclave of Gambia today. The two border crossings will be an adventure in themselves. Don't worry, our tour guide knows the paperwork. Finally, we cross the mighty Gambia River  the namesake of the country we'll get to know more about over the course of our journey. After that, it's about another four hours to our destination for today: the village of Coubalan in Casamance. Here, the Diola people still live in close connection with nature and their cultural heritage. We'll spend the night in a very simple campement in the heart of the village, but this evening we'll experience something very special: the ethnic masked dance, in which the dancers adorn themselves with elaborate costumes, accompanied by rhythmic music and singing. The village community is preparing our dinner today. This is the start of several more days in which we'll get to know the culture of Casamance better. Distance: 250 km Overnight: Campement Coubalang in Coubalan Meals: B, D Day 10  Thurs., November 6, 2025 Coubalan  Cap Skirring Village walks in Coubalan and Kathioune, learning about the traditional architecture and lifestyle of the Diola people Mighty Kapok Trees During a walking tour of the village of Coubalan, with a bit of luck, we might meet the village chief and have him show us the giant kapok trees with their powerful buttress roots that can be found in the village. On the way to Cap Skirring, we visit the village of Kathioune, where a knowledgeable villager shows us the well and a sacred tree. Animism is still widespread in Casamance, and many villages have sacred sites. We continue to Oussouye, where we meet a cooperative of disabled women who are active in handicrafts. With a little luck, we'll meet the only remaining traditional ruler of the Diola ethnic group, the "Mane," in Oussouye, who will tell us about the life of this remarkable community. In Mlomp, we'll learn about the region's extraordinary architecture and visit a two-story mud house. In the early evening, we'll reach Senegal's most beautiful stretch of beach at Cap Skirring. Distance: 150 km Overnight: Campement No Stress** or Hotel Maya** near Cap Skirring Meals: Breakfast Day 11  Fri., November 7, 2025 Cap Skirring Swimming day at Cap Skirring beach or independent exploration Deeply relaxed on the beach Look forward to a perfect swimming day on the beautiful beaches of Cap Skirring, known for their long, soft sandy coastline and crystal-clear, warm waters. These beaches offer the ideal setting to take a break, unwind, and read a book under a palm tree. Use the time and plan your day as you wish. A lie-in, a stroll on the beach, or a refreshing swim  many things are possible today. Those who want to take the opportunity to visit the nearby town of Cap Skirring can take a taxi to experience some of the city's everyday life. Route: - Overnight: Campement No Stress** or Hotel Maya** near Cap Skirring Meals: B Day 12  Sat., November 8, 2025 Cap Skirring  Ziguinchor Open-Air Museum Sangawatt, Sacred Tam-Tam in Siganar, Visit to the Impluvium House in Enampore Immersion in Diola Culture This morning we visit the traditional open-air museum of Sangawatt, dedicated to the culture and animist traditions of the Diola. The museum director will introduce us to the history and way of life of this ethnic group and familiarize us with their animist religion. Afterwards, we will drive towards Ziguinchor. First, we marvel at the village's sacred tam-tam in Siganar, a traditional instrument of communication between the villagers and the neighboring villages. Afterwards, we visit the impluvium house in Enampore and reach our destination for today in the late afternoon. Ziguinchor, the trading center of Casamance, still captivates with its colonial flair. Our centrally located accommodation allows those who are adventurous to explore the town on their own in the evening or go out for dinner. Otherwise, the hotel has a small, cozy courtyard that invites you to linger. Perhaps you'd like to take a dip in the pool! Distance: 190 km Overnight: Le Flamboyant** in Ziguinchor Meals: B Day 13  Sun., November 9, 2025 Ziguinchor  Kassagne Border crossing into Gambia, guided walk or bike tour Pure nature along the Gambia River After about 90 kilometers, we cross the border into Gambia. The small country is completely surrounded by Senegal and was once colonized by Great Britain. At midday, we reach our accommodation in Kassagne, beautifully situated on a tributary of the Gambia River, and have some time to ourselves. In the afternoon, we experience the nature and villages along the mighty river on our guided easy walk or a short, easy mountain bike tour. Distance: 120 km Overnight: AbCa's Creek Lodge*** in Kassagne Meals: B Day 14  Mon., November 10, 2025 Kassagne Boat tour on the Gambia River, afternoon free time On the Gambia River The Gambia River and its tributaries meander majestically through the picturesque landscape of West Africa, providing a beautiful backdrop for our days in the small enclave of Gambia. On our boat tour today, we'll keep an eye out for the colorful birdlife and perhaps encounter some curious monkeys that live here in the mangroves. We'll spend the second half of the day in the relaxed atmosphere of the lodge right on the riverbank, treating ourselves to some time off. Route: - Overnight: AbCa's Creek Lodge*** in Kassagne Meals: B Day 15  Tuesday, November 11, 2025 Kassagne  Banjul Walk in the Makasutu Cultural Forest, Monkey Forest, afternoon free time on the Atlantic Ocean Visit to the Monkey Forest We'll drive westward for one to two hours along dusty tracks along the Gambia River. South of Banjul, we'll stop at the Makasutu Cultural Forest, where we'll take a walk and marvel at the flora and fauna of the nature reserve and enjoy a simple lunch. Continuing our journey, we'll stop at the Bijilo Monkey Forest, where the residents will greet us cheerfully. Our hotel is located in the immediate vicinity, near the beach in one of Banjul's suburbs. There's still time for a swim in the Atlantic Ocean. Distance: 90 km Overnight: Mansea Beach** or Cape Point** near Banjul Meals: B, L Day 16  Wed., November 12, 2025 Banjul City Tour and Market Visit The Cultural Heart of Gambia Look forward to a cultural and historical exploration! Banjul is manageable, and the sights are within walking distance. We'll walk through the city center, past July 22nd Square, along the main shopping street, Liberation Avenue, to the famous Albert Market. Along the way, we'll climb the stairs to Arch 22, from which we'll have a good view of the city. Afterwards, we'll visit the Jamah Mosque and the small National Museum. Afterward, we'll head to the city market. We'll stroll through the narrow streets and explore the colorful stalls with a variety of goods, including handmade crafts, local textiles, spices, fresh fruit and vegetables, and traditional African clothing. We'll end the day in the evening at our hotel on the Atlantic Ocean. Distance: 50 km Overnight: Mansea Beach** or Cape Point** near Banjul Meals: B Day 17  Thursday, November 13, 2025 Banjul  James Island  Toubakouta Ferry ride across the Gambia River, visit to James Island, border crossing into Senegal Transatlantic Slave Trade First, we drive to Banjul and take the ferry across the Gambia River to Barra, then continue upstream to a small jetty. From here, we board a passenger boat to James Island, an island in the heart of the Gambia River. Here, we delve into the fascinating past of this UNESCO World Heritage Site. As an important trading post during the transatlantic slave trade, the island served as a hub for the exchange of goods and people. We explore the well-preserved ruins and learn about dark chapters of history as we walk through the former fortifications and slave cells. At the same time, we enjoy the picturesque beauty of the surrounding river landscape and are impressed by the significance and complexity of this historical site. Back on land, we continue by bus across the border in Karang to Toubakouta. Back in Senegal, we reach the mangrove landscape of the Sine-Saloum Delta in the afternoon. Since 2011, the national park, with its many small islands and waterways, has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Our accommodation is located directly on the water, and after the long bus ride, we find some peace and quiet by the pool. Driving distance: 125 km Overnight: Keur Saloum**(*) near Toubakouta in the Sine-Saloum Delta Meals: B Day 18  Fri., November 14, 2025 Sine-Saloum Delta Learn about the palm wine harvest and sustainable oyster fishing, explore the Sine-Saloum Delta by pirogue The Spirits of the Serer and Mandinka Today, in the heart of the bush, we will gain an insight into the palm wine harvest, where skilled harvesters climb dangerously to the treetops to collect the palm wine in bottles. In the village of Sangako, we will meet women from a cooperative who, after a short walk to the mangroves, will tell us about ecologically sustainable oyster fishing. We will also explore the beauty of the Sine-Saloum Delta with its lagoons, small islands, mighty baobabs, and mangrove forests aboard a pirogue. We sail through this peaceful and natural world and enjoy the numerous birds that call it home. We then discover a small shell island where the deceased Serer and Mandinka were buried (their spirits are said to still be here today). Enjoy stunning views before we explore the small tributaries of the delta by pirogue and, with a little luck, observe birds such as pelicans, kingfishers, bee-eaters, weaver birds, and red-necked falcons. Route: - Overnight: Keur Saloum**(*) near Toubakouta in the Sine-Saloum Delta Meals: B Day 19  Sat., November 15, 2025 Sine-Saloum Delta  Saly Village visits on the way to the Petite Cte, with a communal farewell dinner in the evening Conclusion at the Petite Cte We spend the last days of our trip on the Petite Cte. Along the way, we'll visit a few villages to interact with locals and stretch our legs. Halfway through, in Foundiougne, we'll cross the Sine River one last time and approach the palm-fringed coastline south of Dakar. Endless sandy beaches stretch out here, inviting you to relax and enjoy the tropical sun. The perfect end to an eventful trip through Senegambia. A farewell dinner will be held in the evening. Today is your last day with your tour guide, as tomorrow we'll be spending time on the beach. Distance: 165 km Overnight: Les Bougainvilles*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: B, D Day 20  Sun., November 16, 2025 Saly  Dakar  Return flight Beach day or time for independent exploration and return flight Beach relaxation and return flight Today everyone has time to stroll along the beach again, enjoy the sea, and jump in. We'll take it easy before our flight and allow ourselves time to unwind. Day rooms are still available at the hotel (one room for four guests each). From Saly, the international airport is just under an hour away. Au revoir, Sngal! Distance: 40 km Overnight stay: Airplane, one day room for four people each at Les Bougainvilles*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: Breakfast Day 21  Monday, November 17, 2025 Arrival Arrival and Departure Back Home We usually arrive in Frankfurt around lunchtime. You can reach your hometown by train, which is environmentally friendly and free of charge within Germany. Distance: - Overnight stay: - Meals: as per onboard service Tour guide Lamine, 68, was born in Senegal. He studied both English and German at the University of Dakar. He has been working as a tour guide for Senegal and Gambia for over 25 years. It is a great pleasure for him to show our groups his country with all its cultural diversity and to let us experience the hospitality of the Senegalese. Lamine Seck is one of our WORLD INSIGHT tour guides in Senegal and the Gambia. Travel Information Open all Entry Requirements & Vaccinations Senegal: A passport valid for at least 6 months beyond the end of the trip is required. A valid yellow fever vaccination is officially required for all arrivals from a yellow fever area (according to the WHO, Gambia is a yellow fever infection area). Vaccinations against yellow fever, hepatitis A, and poliomyelitis are recommended. Depending on individual indications, additional vaccinations against dengue fever, hepatitis B, meningococcal ACWY, rabies, and typhoid are recommended. A cholera vaccination is generally not necessary. Gambia: A passport valid for at least 6 months beyond the end of the trip and a visa are required. You will receive the visa upon entry. A valid yellow fever vaccination is officially required for all arrivals from a yellow fever area (Senegal is a yellow fever infection area according to the WHO). Vaccination against hepatitis A is recommended. If individually indicated, additional vaccinations against dengue fever, hepatitis B, meningococcus ACWY, rabies and typhoid are advised. A cholera vaccination is generally not necessary. Note: The entry regulations apply to German, Austrian and Swiss citizens. We will be happy to provide information to other EU citizens after they have provided their nationality, or they can find out more directly here. Unless otherwise stated, at least a machine-readable passport valid for 6 months at the end of the trip and with two blank, facing pages is required. Citizens of other nations outside the EU should contact their responsible authority. Requirements & travel-specific information No special requirements. Normal physical fitness and health are sufficient. A high degree of adaptability, openness, and tolerance is expected on this trip, as the journey often takes place over poor roads and some overnight stays are simple. Road conditions change constantly, even at short notice, which is why we cannot provide reliable information on travel times and why minor changes to the program may occur. The itinerary includes numerous visits to families, artisans, artists, initiatives, etc. Please note that individual program items may vary or even be omitted. Occasionally, these spontaneous visits cannot be arranged due to personal or other reasons on the part of the hosts. The tour guide will endeavor to accommodate such cases. We ask for an openness to spontaneity, as this is the only way the trip can maintain its character as a journey of encounters with plenty of contact with locals. For the mountain bike tour on day 13, simple men's bikes will be provided, the condition of which may not always meet current safety standards. Meals: Breakfast is included daily on this trip, and dinner on some days as well. Vegetarians are asked to note this when registering. You will find the meals marked in the trip description with B=breakfast, L=lunch/picnic, D=dinner. On-site team Our cheerful team with Bijou and Abdoulaye supports our Country Manager Khalifa in the office in Dakar. Together with them, we planned our varied Senegal and Gambia trip down to the last detail, as they are our on-site experts. Khalifa has always been passionate about bringing his country's culture closer to travelers, and so he opened his agency in 2004. Our German-speaking Senegalese tour guides have many years of experience, spent several years in Germany, and speak good German. They will show you their homeland with commitment, professionalism, and even more fun, so that you will always remember it. Our team in Senegal and Gambia Khalifa, our Country Manager in Senegal and Gambia Local transport In Senegal and Gambia we use typical local minibuses, which can vary in size depending on the group size. The buses usually have air conditioning and windows that open. Luggage is usually carried on the roof. At Pink Lake, we take a trip in an old military vehicle. There are no seatbelts here. One of our minibuses in Senegal and Gambia. One of our minibuses in Senegal and Gambia. One of our minibuses (interior view) in Senegal and Gambia. Flight information: As a tour operator, we do not yet have the final flight times. For your convenience, we would be happy to share the provisional flight schedule of the respective airline with you. This currently looks like this: TAP Air Portugal: Outbound flight Frankfurt - Lisbon 1:25 p.m. - 3:35 p.m. Lisbon - Dakar 8:45 p.m. - 1:00 a.m. (+1) Return flight Dakar - Lisbon 2:00 a.m. - 6:00 a.m. Lisbon - Frankfurt 8:20 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. (+1) = Arrival the following day Country information Download country information: Gambia Download country information: Senegal Accommodations On this trip we stay in well-maintained and well-located ***** hotels. All rooms have a bathroom or shower/WC. In Coubalan we spend one night in a very simply furnished campement in brick huts with thatched roofs and shared bathrooms. To refresh yourself after an eventful day, some accommodations have a swimming pool. Depending on the number of participants, the group in Cap Skirring can be split between two accommodations that are within walking distance of each other.
